story: A BERWICKSHIRE man will stand trial at Jedburgh Sherf Court accused of voyeurism.David Virtue is accused of taking photographs of a womans naked body without her knowledge or consent at a house in Westruther between March  and March , .The -year-old of Cedarwood, Gordon, will stand trial on May  with an intermediate hearing on March .

title: fundraising-begins-for-fish-shop-extension-plans-in-selkirk
story: A FRESH fundraising drive is about to begin in Selkirk to conclude work on a new community-owned shop.After lying dormant for more than two decades the former fish shop in Tower Street was brought back into use at the end of last year by the Selkirk Regeneration Company.Now the charity wants to renovate the rest of the property to turn it into a new community space.And they hope to start eating into the pound, price tag by hosting a fundraising sale later this month.David Bethune treasurer of Selkirk Regeneration Company told us: "Using virtually every last penny of our resources, we completed temporary redecoration of the front shop to allow it to be used as a second pop-up shop in the run up to Christmas."The next stage is to complete the renovation of the whole property, including rebuilding the back shop, to turn it into a fully accessible community resource."Plans have been drawn up, and while we hope most of the cost can be raised from grants, some will need to come from the community itself."During Friday and Saturday, February  and , the Selkirk Regeneration Company will hold a sale of unwanted presents and second-hand items at the neighbouring corner pop-up shop at  Tower Street.Mr Bethune added: "There will probably also be some baking and other goodies, so make sure you pop in to see what is for sale, and so help fund the renovation of the old fish shop."Anyone who would like ot donate items can hand them into  Tower Street on the Tuesday or Wednesday, February  and .Alternativelyyou would like items collected call Mr Bethune on  .

title: chloe-and-oscar-pull-on-their-hats-in-memory-of-dad
story: A BORDERS brother and sister who lost their father to a brain tumour are starring in a marketing campaign to help raise funds for finding a cure for the disease.Chloe Lowther, , and her nine-year-old brother Oscar are featuring in this yearrsquos national Wear A Hat Day campaign by the Brain Tumour Research charity.The Peebles siblings were invited to take part to represent Scotland and their images will be seen across the country as the campaign is launched ready for Brain Tumour Awareness month in March.Across the UK, other children who have either been bereaved by a brain tumour, are living with a brain tumour or have a close family member who has been diagnosed, are also taking part to represent their regions.They are all donning their best headwear from beanies to cowboy hats, trilbies to Panamas, baseball caps to novelty headpieces, and are asking others to join them for Wear A Hat Day, which takes place on Friday, March .The event is expected to smash all records as it marks its th year.Chloe and Oscarrsquos dad Matt was diagnosed after collapsing at home with an aggressive and incurable glioblastoma multormebrain tumour.Despite undergoing surgery and chemotherapy and radiotherapy treatment, Matt passed away less than two years later, aged , in March , not long after his th wedding anniversary.Mum Gill, a teaching secretary at Edinburgh College of Art, said: ldquoWhen Matt was diagnosed, we were told that the average le expectancy of this type of tumour was  to  months."The grieving process for me started  months before Matt died as the two of us came to terms with the idea that we were not going to have the le together we planned."I spent a lot of time listening to a playlist we compiled which represented our  years together.ldquoNow I am doing my best to give our children the childhood we had planned together.ldquoI am so proud of Oscar and Chloe for being part of the Wear A Hat Day campaign."It means so much to my family and me to help contribute towards a cure, so itrsquos an honour to have them take part. Chloe and Oscar had such a fun time at the photoshoot too and it will be a lovely memento for them to look back on.Wear A Hat Day also has the backing of supermodel, businesswoman and brain tumour survivor Caprice who underwent surgery to remove a meningioma brain tumour two years ago.A patron of Brain Tumour Research, Caprice plays a key role in raising awareness of the disease and campaigning for the government and the larger cancer charities to increase national investment in research. Also supporting this yearrsquos fundraiser is Strictly Come Dancing finalist Debbie McGee who lost her magician husband Paul Daniels to the disease three years ago.Corporate supporters already signed up for the fundraiser include Specsavers, Hobbycraft, and Venture Studios ndash the latter worked with families across the UK who have been affected by brain tumours to create the stunning portraits used in the campaign.,params: .pushAlso taking part will be hundreds of schools, workplaces, and iniduals who will don their hat of choice and hold a whole host of hat-themed fundraising events in support of Brain Tumour Research.Sue Farrington Smith, Chief Executive of Brain Tumour Research, told us: ldquoWe are extremely grateful to Chloe and Oscar and their mum for helping us to launch Wear A Hat Day ."I know that people will be both distressed and inspired to hear the stories of all of these families who, like my own, know the pain of a brain tumour diagnosis.ldquoWe are entirely committed to easing this pain by improving treatment options for patients and, ultimately, finding a cure. Brain tumours kill more children and adults under the age of  than any other cancer yet, historically, just one percent of the national spend on cancer research has been allocated to this devastating disease Brain Tumour Research is proud to be changing this.ldquoThe sad truth is that brain tumours are indiscriminate and can affect anyone at any age and this means the impact on families is enormous. Too many children are losing siblings, parents and grandparents, too many parents are enduring the agony of their childrsquos diagnosis, and society as a whole continues to bear the burden of increased costs through the NHS, lost taxes, and demands on the benefits system.Wear A Hat Day has raised over a million pounds since the launch of Brain Tumour Research  years ago.The big day will see schools, workplaces, families and iniduals across the UK fundraising and taking part in fun events to raise awareness of brain tumours and help fund le-saving research.Funds raised will develop the charityrsquos network of brain tumour research centres in the UK where scientists are focused on improving outcomes for patients and, ultimately, finding a cure.To get involved, or donate, please visit: www.wearahatday.org or text HAT to  to donate pound.

title: gales-of-up-to-60mph-set-to-batter-the-borders
story: GALE force winds of up to mph are forecast to batter the Borders this weekend.The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning from midday on Friday until pm on Saturday.And Borderers are being warned to expect power cuts and travel disruption.^Photo: Met OfficeA spokesperson for the Met Office said: "A spell of very strong winds is expected to affect large parts of the UK leading to some travel disruption."Some delays to road, rail, air and ferry transport are likely delays for high-sided vehicles on exposed routes and bridges are likely some short term loss of power and other services is possible and itrsquos possible that some coastal routes, sea fronts and coastal communities could be affected by spray and or large waves."

title: five-star-pupils-take-over-peeblesshire-hotel
story: THE old adage about policemen getting younger didnt used to apply to hotel staff.But anyone visiting Cringletie House Hotel on a Tuesday morning can now be forgiven for feeling that little bit older.A pioneering project between Peebles High Schools home economics department and the boutique hotel near Eddleston is allowing third-year pupils take over the kitchen, restaurant, offices and bedrooms.Initiated by Developing the Young Workforce Borders, it is hoped the five-week-long placement will inspire many into the hospitality and tourism industry.Sara Ward, project manager at DYW Borders, told us: "This initiative will showcase the many opportunities that are available within the hospitality, travel and tourism sector."Tourism is one of the largest growth sectors in the Scottish Borders and pupils will be given the opportunity to develop many transferable skills which in turn can prepare them for making the transition to world of work."The project has been devised as a direct reaction to an unexpected shortfall in hospitality workers from overseas following Brexit.And it is hoped the scheme will also raise the profile of Cringletie as a possible place of employment for local school-leavers.Throughout February and into March, pupils will spend every Tuesday morning shadowing staff.And on their final morning the pupils will operate the hotel and serve up lunch for invited guests, including parents, local business and friends.Jeremy Osborne, general manager at Cringletie, said: ldquoThe Cringletie team had a brilliant response from the pupils and over the next few weeks it will only go from strength to strength."This has to be the way forward to encourage young people in to hospitality and show it is a job that is fun, skilful and there always be one for those who want to get on in le.Although the pilot project has just started this week, home economics teacher Kirsty Williams is delighted with the experience her pupils are enjoying.She said: "We would like to thank Cringletie for affording our students this fabulous opportunity at a time when they are making important decisions about their futures."This programme has opened their eyes to the erse range of career paths available within Hospitality and has enhanced their learning tremendously."

title: supermarket-giant-lidl-eyes-up-move-to-galashiels
story: SUPERMARKET giant Lidl has expressed interest in opening a store in Galashiels.Last month an application was submitted to Scottish Borders Council to allow the sale of food goods at units currently occupied by Carpetright and Currys at Comley Bank Mill Retail Park.And Nectar Asset Management, which put in the plans, says there has been interest from the German discount chain to take over one of the buildings.The application states: "This condition iation is sought due to current market uncertainty and to provide greater flexibility should one or both of the units become vacant in the short to medium term."Carpetright announced their CVAin  and the unit was put on the market via [real estate company] Colliers in May ."No enquiries were received whatsoever except for from Lidl in December."As a result there is a high risk that this unit and potentially the entire park could be become vacant in  when all three leases expire unless the consent is widened."It is therefore anticipated that the units could be combined and occupied by Lidl who are a deep-discount food store operator and have shown interest in the premises."Lidl currently has two stores in the Borders, in Kelso and in Hawick.

title: former-scotland-star-could-have-galashiels-street-named-after-him
story: A STREET in Galashiels could be named after former Scotland footballer John Collins.The towns community council has been asked to come up with a list of suggestions for three unnamed roads at Melrose Gait.And at a meeting on Wednesday night the former Celtic and Hibs star, who is now an ambassador at Gala Fairydean Rovers, was unveiled as one of the options.Chairwoman of the community council Judith Cleghorn said: "Alison Wallace from Scottish Borders Council has been in touch to get our suggestions to name three streets at the Melrose Gait estate."The councillors have come up with some suggestions on who to name the streets after and it would be good to get peoples thoughts."Among the famous names put forward was George Hope Tait ndash a poet and town councillor who is also recognised for his contribution to art, architecture, journalism and authorship in the town.Naming a street after one of Galashiels greatest servants, Bill Lamb, was another idea.Mr Lamb, who died last year, was a local councillor for  years.He held several portfolio posts when the Liberal Democrats were in power at Newtown St Boswells.And community councillor Drew Tulley put forward former local government officer George Knox, who died ten years ago.The former Town Clerk was honoured by Her Majesty the Queen in  when he was awarded the Queens Jubilee Medal and again in , when he was given an MBE for his long service in local government in the region.Mr Tulley said: "I would suggest George Knox as an option because of the work he did for this town."I would have liked to have seen a street named after him in the centre of town."I think it is a shame that he hasnt already got a street named after him in Galashiels."

title: chef-cameron-sheds-more-than-eight-stones
story: A PEEBLES chef left his career creating mouth-watering dishes at an award-winning hotel to fight the war on obesity.When former Head Chef of Cringletie House Hotel Cameron MacMichael hit st lb in April , he squeezed into his chef whites with a  inch waist.Looking in the mirror unhappy at the large reflection staring back at him, he made a decision to turn his le around and his incredible weight loss journey to health and happiness began.Cameron worked under Executive Masterchef Chef Willie Pike MBE, one of Scotlandrsquos top chefs who taught him the secret art of blown sugar.This talent would soon become Cameronrsquos crowning glory, and he was renowned for creating realistic fruits filled with sorbet as the core.Cameron also spent time in the kitchen with famed chef Ivan Day, who is acclaimed as the leading expert on historic cookery in Britain.Cameron told us: ldquoIvan has mentored chefs such as Heston Blumenthal, so I was lucky enough to be given the opportunity to learn from him. The skills I learned from Ivan inspired me to create Outlander themed wedding menus for the hotel.Success continued to grow for the award-winning chef, but so did his waistline, and surrounded by food, it constantly became a battle to control the pounds as they crept on.ldquoI simply didnrsquot want to develop long term health problems, Cameron told the Peeblesshire News.ldquoI wanted to become me again.After trying and struggling with countless diets, Cameron turned to the Cambridge plan in a last ditch attempt to gain control of his weight.It would fast become the best decision he ever made after losing a whopping st lbs in nine short months.Cameron explained: ldquoThe diet was not plain sailing, working in the kitchen I was always tempted to eat the wrong kids of foods constantly."It is so easy to cook a quick fix when yoursquore hungry which is usually deep fried.With a new attitude to food, Cameron says the one-to-one support from consultants is perfect for taking control and managing weight.But what drove this incredibly successful and driven chef to hang up his apron and turn up the gas on a new career as Cambridge Weight Loss Consultant.Cameron explained: ldquoI left the kitchen to join the war on obesity which is linked to causing one out of  deaths in Britain.ldquoMy former Cambridge mentors Mark and Nicola Lafferty said I should consider becoming a consultant."With my own success story, vast knowledge of food and the drive to help others, I was seeing clients within the week I was accredited as a consultant.The former chef may have left the hotel industry, but he is still very much doing what he loves - which is creating new dishes.And he is very excited about the launch of his first cook book.ldquoUsing my knowledge of food, I am creating dishes that are  calories. I want to make meals simple, tasty and fun so even the kids can get involved.Cameron hopes to have his cook book published and available to buy this summer.Askedhe had any regrets leaving le as a hotel chef behind, Cameron replied: ldquoIrsquom still a chef, just not for people who want to be cooked for. I now create dishes for people to cook themselves at home which will hopefully enable them to lead a healthy lestyle and take back control.Cameron is based at Cavalry Park, Peebles and can be contacted via Facebook: Cameron MacMichael Independent Consultant Cambridge Weight Plan.Ends.

title: lidl-hopes-to-make-announcement-soon-on-new-borders-store
story: SUPERMARKET giant Lidl is hoping to make an announcement soon on bringing a new store to the Borders.Yesterday the Borderrevealed the German discount chain was eyeing up a move to Galashiels.Last month an application was submitted to Scottish Borders Council to allow the sale of food goods at units currently occupied by Carpetright and Currys at Comley Bank Mill Retail Park.And Nectar Asset Management, which put in the plans, said there was interest from Lidl to take over one of the buildings in December.Now supermarket bosses have confirmed they have a number of options on the table.A spokesperson for Lidl said: "We are in the process of exploring ious options to bring another new Lidl to the Scottish Borders and look forward to sharing any firm plans with the community when a site has been identied."The chain currently has two stores in the Borders, in Kelso and in Hawick.

title: out-of-school-club-is-quids-in-following-online-draw
story: AN out of school club in Jedburgh is celebrating after becoming the first winners of a Borders businesss first giveaway.The online directory Borders offered a prize of pound through social media to a worthy local cause.Despite entries from across the region it was the Jedburgh Out of School Club that was drawn out of the hat.A spokesman for the club told us: "This is a massive windfall."The much-needed funds will be a substantial help towards outdoor equipment for the children."Joining manager Kelli Wild to collect the winning cheque was parent-helper Lorna Pender, who entered the club into the draw.

title: a-tribute-to-buddy-holly
story: SIXTY years ago on February  , Rock rsquonrsquo Roll lost a legend ndash Buddy Holly. To commemorate the anniversary, tribute show Buddy Holly and The Cricketers are presenting a special performance in venues all over the UK. Tonightthe band will aim to raise the roof of the Eastgate Theatre with songs including all time favourites such as Thatrsquoll Be The Day, Peggy Sue, Heartbeat, It Doesnrsquot Matter Anymore, Raining In My Heart, Oh Boy! He said: ldquoBuddy Holly was pivotal in my development as a guitarist and songwriter.ldquoBuddyrsquos music has touched the hearts of millions around the world and influenced many famous artists such as The Beatles, The Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton, Brian May and many others.ldquoThis year is especially poignant and will be a show to remember.The Buddy Holly and The Cricketers show has been performed for  years and has travelled the world. title: 41-year-old-faces-six-bogus-builder-offences-in-the-borders
story: A -year-old man has appeared in private at Jedburgh Sherf Court accused of six bogus-builder fraud offences.Peter Coyle of Market Street, Duns, also faces a seventh charge of theft.The offences are alleged to have been committed at ious locations in the Borders between January , , and June .He made no plea and the case was continued for further examination.Coyle was released on bail by Sherf Andrew Ferguson with conditions.

title: there-was-an-old-lady-who-swallowed-a-fly-comes-to-the-stage-at-tait-hall-kelso
story: A STAGE version of a much-loved nursery rhyme is coming to Kelso.lsquoThere was an Old Lady who Swallowed a Flyrsquo promises a musical family treat when it arrives in the town next Wednesday.The show, part of Live Bordersrsquo spring  programme, is an adaptation of the comic rhyme telling the tale of a woman who swallows animals.First written as a song in , it was a chart-topping hit for singer and actor, Burl Ives before being adapted into a best-selling book by Pam Adams a few years later.The book is celebrating its th anniversary this year.To mark the occasion, popular childrenrsquos author, Steven Lee has turned the tale into a magical, musical stage show written especially for children to enjoy with their parents.Hamish Moir, programming and events officer at Live Borders said: ldquolsquoThere was an Old Lady who Swallowed a Flyrsquo is an iconic childrenrsquos book and we canrsquot wait to see it performed in the lovely Tait Hall.ldquoAs a charity, we want to see these town halls used for all the community and this is the first in a series of family-centred events coming to our halls in the Borders.The show will be performed by The Peoplersquos Theatre Company at Tait Hall. Doors open at pm, show starts at .pm.Ticketsare pound and can be booked by calling and online from www.liveborders.org.uk. The show is suitable for children aged two and above.

title: cycling-national-park-calls-from-peebles-businessman
story: THE events organiser who brought TweedLove to the Borders is leading calls for the region to become Scotlands first National Park for Cycling.Neil Dalgliesh has helped stage and promote hundreds of two-wheeled events in the area over the past decade.And the closed-road sportives, downhill races and international enduros have boosted the local economy by millions.Now the Peebles-based businessman feels a move to national park status would enhance the regions reputation even further as a cycling destination.He told us: "It was a Scot ndash John Muir - who invented the concept of national parks, and another Scot - Kirkpatrick Macmillan ndash who invented the pedal bicycle, so it seems fitting that we should invent the first National Park for Cycling."We have something internationally unique and extremely valuable right here in the Scottish Borders, and itrsquos the envy of many places around the planet ndash not least just over the border in England."Not only do we have a world class collection of mountain bike trails and off-road tracks, we also have access legislation in Scotland which gives everyone the right to roam on them."Itrsquos also extremely signicant that we have a huge network of quiet tarmac roads through stunning countryside ndash itrsquos an undiscovered road cycling heaven.TweedLoves  events alone produced economic benefit valued at pound, by Scottish Borders Council.While the Tweed Valley - Peebles and Innerleithen in particular - enjoying the financial benefits from cycling, Mr Dalgleish believes national park status would spread the two-wheeled windfall further.He added: "Therersquos a chance to spread that benefit and give recognition to a wider area.ldquoThe areas surrounding the lsquocycling honey potsrsquo are usually overlooked, but have amazing scenery, beautul hill tracks and most importantly some fantastic road cycling to offer.ldquoWe need to be proud of these assets and let the world know what we have to offer."Declaring ourselves a national park for cycling would be big news for cyclists all over the world, but it wouldnrsquot need millions of pounds of investment to deliver.

title: matt-to-pipe-between-the-pages-at-border-libraries
story: TRADITIONAL toe-tapping is coming to a library near you this spring.Borders piper Matt Seattle will be checking into Hawick, Kelso and Galashiels libraries for a series of intimate performances.Matt has performed with a range of international musicians during a successful career.And he also had a starring solo role in the performance by the Scottish Chamber Orchestra of the musical commission for the opening of the Waverley Line.But the performances within the book aisles will be a first - even for Matt.Julia Cawthorne, assistant librarian at Live Borders, told us: ldquoLive Borders Libraries are delighted to be hosting this series of three events in libraries by Matt Seattle."Matt is well respected within the traditional music world and the events promise to be interesting and lively, with each one featuring a dferent selection of tunes for each library venue, Hawick, Galashiels and Kelso.On Thursday, February  at the Hawick Library, Matts performance will feature Walter Ballantyne, Toun Piper of Hawick, The Mystery of the Two Teribus Tunes, and Rattlinrsquo Roarinrsquo Willie of Teviotdale.At the Kelso Library on Tuesday, March , his performance will be John Anderson, My Jo, Toun Piper of Kelso, lsquoAn amourous wag in his dayrsquo and tunes of the Yetholm Gypsies.The finale at Galashiels Library on Thursday, March  features Donald Maclean, Toun Piper of Galashiels, Secrets of the Soor Plums and the Braw Lads.Julia added: "At Live Borders, we believe that libraries play an essential part in the community and we want to encourage audiences to come and see for themselves the wide range of services we have on offer."To book tickets for any of the performances, which all take place between .pm and .pm, call  , email libraries@liveborders.org.uk or visit the host library.

title: innerleithen-to-have-its-say-on-affordable-home-requirements
story: INNERLEITHEN residents are being encouraged to have their say on future housing in the town.Scottish Borders Housing Association will be sending out a survey to all households in the area this month.They want opinion on what is needed in terms of affordable housing in the anonymous questionnaire which will help shape plans for development in the town.Rural Housing Scotland have been commissioned by SBHA to carry out the survey in a bid to engage residents.Chief Executive of Rural Housing Scotland Derek Logie, addressed members of Innerleithen Community Council at a meeting this week.He said: ldquoBy carrying out this survey we want to find out what kind of housing locals feel is needed should theybuild in the future.ldquoWe will be looking attherersquos any new household emerging young people here wanting to leave home. Also people who are living in overcrowded conditions, older people who want to downsize or those who need specialised provision.Askedthis survey was to be carried out where in Tweeddale, Mr Logie said the housing association requested that it was specically Innerleithen.Mr Logie explained: ldquoYou find in the larger communities it is quite easy to demonstrate the need for housing because there are big long waiting lists. In smaller communities where maybe the turnover is less frequent because people donrsquot put their name down so much you have to dig below the surface to find out what is needed.Scottish Borders Councillor Stuart Bell askedthere was a minimum response to have a statistically valid survey.Mr Logie replied: ldquoWe hope to get something like  percent back which tends to be the average. The quantity is not so important, itrsquos the quality in thateverybody that responded said they have housing needs they can respond to that.Councillor Bell stressed that the problem across the Borders is that there is no clear quantication of affordable housing need per community large or small.He added: ldquoI think itrsquos curious and helpful that you are doing this. I was at a meeting of the planning committee and we were sitting looking at a planning application which was focussed on Peebles and we donrsquot know the affordable housing need in Peebles. There isnrsquot a number you can say the demand is X.ldquoThere is evidence of some support, which is that the Chief Executive of Eildon Housing, Nile Istephan said the last time they were advertising properties in Peebles the got  for each property. To a degree that is representative but we donrsquot know what the affordable accommodation need is in not just Peebles, but Walkerburn, Innerleithen and West Linton, which are numbers we ought to know in order for informed decisions to be taken.ldquoIrsquom really pleased yoursquore doing this, Irsquod just like to see it done in other communities also.Residents are being urged to complete the survey which can be completed by hand or electronically. Results will be available mid-March .

title: pet-of-the-week
story: This weeks Pet Of The Week, from Borders Pet Rescue, features a pair of four-year-old Musk Turtles.The charity told us: "They came in to us as their owner sadly passed away. They dont really take much looking after and both seem quite happy and healthy so would make great pets for someone. They must be rehomed together."We have recently moved them into a bigger tank here at the centre with more enrichment and they are showing how active and interesting they can be to watch, so they would need the same type of set up in their new home."If you would like to offer them a forever home, please email info@borderspetrescue.org for an application."

title: breath-of-fresh-air-as-cheyne-gang-turns-one
story: COMMUNITY singing group Tweed Valley Cheyne Gang is celebrating its first birthday.The Innerleithen-based choir was set up last year for people living with long-term respiratory conditions such as COPD , asthma and bronchiectasis.The aim is to encourage singers to use better breathing techniques, undertake a gentle physical workout and have a lot of fun.And the gang has had a busy first year.Not only has it met fortnightly in Innerleithen but, along with the other Cheyne Gang groups in Edinburgh, has performed at Jupiter Artland with The Nevis Ensemble and sung at the Scottish Parliament at the launch of Chest Heart and Stroke Scotlandrsquos report on the need for more rehabilitation servicesThe group has taken part in the Edinburgh Book Festival, raised funds locally through a coffee morning and is currently taking part in research with medical students from Edinburgh University.Voice coach, Julie Harvey has been delighted with the progress of the group.She said:ldquoIt has been a huge privilege to work as a voice coach with The Cheyne Gang over the past  months.ldquoThe Borders group has been a huge success thanks to our amazing singers, our helpers, our local community in Tweeddale and the Cheyne Gang team in Edinburgh.ldquoI believe passionately in the positive impact singing can have on our physical and mental health and well-being, and in our everyday le.ldquoWe have a lot of fun at the Cheyne Gang sessions, but we also take our work with people on breathing and managing breathlessness seriously.The group was launched in the Tweed Valley in January last year and already has a core of  people who attend regularly.They are also open for new singers. Member Ian said: ldquoThe singing exercises I perform during my fortnightly session at the Cheyne Gang have not only eased my breathing dficulties, I have also found them so easy to do at home.ldquoThe group of folk attending the sessions make you feel so welcome as does the music teacher.ldquoCongratulations to everyone involved on the first anniversary of our Cheyne Gang.ldquoWhy not come along and join us and feel the dference it makes to your breathing The next session is on Thursday, February , then Wednesday, March , from -pm in the Union Club, Peebles Road, Innerleithen.If you think the Cheyne Gang is something that might help you oryou work for NHS and would like to find out more about what they do, pop along to one of the sessions or contact Anne Ritchie at anne@thecheynegang.

title: andrew-and-jim-set-to-revive-forgotten-gems
story: POPULAR Scottish classics are to be served up at the Hawick Music Club later this month.The Agapanthus Duo will take to the stage at the Heart of Hawick on Sunday, February .Pianist Andrew Sherwood and violinist Jim Letham bring with them vast experience and a repertoire of great music.The duo champion many neglected Scottish composers.Jim, who was one-time president of Hawick Music Club, is a composer, pianist, educator and conductor of several choirs including the Abbey Consort.And has done a great deal to support and promote all forms of music in the Borders.Andrew grew up in Africa where he first picked up the violin as a teenager.A scholarship to the Royal College of Music led to a break with the Royal Opera House before freelancing in British orchestras including the Scottish Camber Orchestra and leading the Mercury Ensemble for Ballet Rambert.Performing has always gone hand in hand with teaching and he has been professor of violin at Trinity Labon Conservatoire for many years.His students visit the Borders every year and perform in Hawick.The Agapanthus Duo concert in Hawick starts at .pm on Sunday, February .Ticketsfor non-members are priced at pound for adults and free for accompanied under s.They are available from the Heart of Hawick box office on  .

title: colleges-salute-to-armed-forces
story: BORDERS College has nailed its colours to the mast by signing the Armed Forces Covenant.Signing the covenant demonstrates that the college recognises the value serving personnel, reservists, veterans and military families bring to the college.The college said that, by becoming a forces-friendly employer, it can benefit from the wide range of skills and experiences that reservists and veterans can bring to the organisation.Principal Angela Cox, Access to Unorm Services students and lecturer Damien Asquith , together with head of HR Debbie Kerr and head of student services Clare Nairn, all teamed up to sign the agreement.The college aims to uphold the principles of the Armed Forces Covenant including: promoting its armed forces-friendly status seeking to support the employment of veterans striving to support the employment and training of service spouses and partners flexibility in granting leave for service spouses and partners supporting employees who choose to be members of the reserve forces offering support to local cadet units and participating in Armed Forces Day.

title: cast-of-les-miserables-bring-barricades-to-hawick
story: STARS of the musical, Les Miseacuterables are coming to the Borders.Recreating West End and Broadway musical hit songs with amazing authenticity, the cast of past principal performers from Les title: st-ronans-honour-the-bard
story: THE pupils of St. Ronanrsquos School in Innerleithen once again honoured the Bard by holding their th Annual Burns Lunch last week.As well as celebrating the birth of Robert Burns, the event commemorated the poets visit to Innerleithen in  when he took tea at Pirn House, where the school now stands.The schoolrsquos lunch was arranged by the Primary  pupils with guests from the community as well as the Primary  pupils and senior pupils from partner school, Walkerburn.In the chair was Sarah Whiteford who kept the proceedings moving along nicely.Piper Jim Hamilton, of Innerleithen Pipe Band, piped in the haggis, and Frances Reilly gave a stirring Address to the Haggis, albeit being a pre-recorded version on the big screen, as Frances was part of the Netball Team battling it out in the Borders School Final.The girls finished runners-up and ed in time for the speeches.Oliver Kennedy said the Selkirk Grace before a team of Primary  waiters and waitresses served up a delicious meal of haggis, neeps and tatties prepared by the St Ronanrsquos kitchen staff.Following the meal, a number of pupils delivered well-researched and humorous speeches.Freya Wilson proposed The Immortal Memory, which was accompanied by an imaginative slideshow.Freya reminded everyone of the Bardrsquos humble beginnings, his visit to Innerleithen and his colourful lestyle.The Toast to the Lassies was proposed by Marcus Adam who recounted Burnsrsquo love of the lassies, while taking the chance to gently poke fun at the girls, ultimately acknowledging that he couldnrsquot live without them.Eve Rathie replied on behalf of the lasses and managed to get a bit of her own back.Other toasts and replies were given by Eilish Henderson , Kylib Crawfordand Josh Landers .The Primary  and  pupils from Walkerburn - Ruby Patterson, Kaden Hunter, Melissa Lucas, Thomas Wilson and Kayleigh Zokas - delivered the reply on behalf of the Guests.St Ronans headteacher Keith Belleville told us: "Each young person taking part was very accomplished in the delivery of their role."The lunch was packed full of entertainment."The choir sang two songs with the children from Primary one getting in on the act with a Scottish version of the Hokey Cokey: The Shooglie Wooglie and a video link to the Nursery saw the children there present a Scottish medley.Throughout the afternoon the winners of the whole school Scots poetry recitation competition had entertained with their verses, which ranged from the works of J.K. Annand to Burns himself and showed off the considerable talent from across the school.The chief guest for the day was Alan Patterson, chairman of St. Ronanrsquos Border Games, who was joined by his we Dawn.Mr Patterson gave an inspiring address before presenting the awards to the winners of the poetry competition.The Burns Lunch closed with the singing of ldquoAuld Lang Syne.

title: belfast-street-was-a-blueprint-for-n-ireland-ballymurphy-inquest-told
story: A west Belfast street was a ldquoblueprint for Northern Ireland in , with Catholics and Protestants living side by side in harmony ndash but the introduction of internment destroyed it in one night, an inquest has heard.Bobby Clarke, , who survived a series of shootings in which  people died between August -, , also said he feels responsible after two people were shot dead coming to his aid, describing that as a ldquovery heavy burden to bear.Mr Clarke was giving evidence to the inquest that is examining the deaths of  people in Ballymurphy in .Robert lsquoBobbyrsquo Clarke with Patsy Mullan, the brother of Father Hugh Mullan who was shot and died The sequence of events started after the introduction of internment in Northern Ireland that year on August . Mass arrests sparked rioting across the region.Over three days, from August -,  people died in shootings at a number of locations in west Belfast.The events have become known as the Ballymurphy Massacre.Mr Clarke was shot on an area of waste ground close to Springfield Park known as the field on the evening of August .He had been at work that day and as he ed home, he heard there had been disturbances in the area all day. He evacuated his we and two young children before ing to protect his house.Upon his , he told the inquest he saw women who were hysterical and he suggested moving people to nearby New Barnsley.He delivered a baby to safety and was making his way back across the field to help others when he described believing that two soldiers sitting on a roof of flats in the Springmartin road were tracking him with their rles, he had started to zigzag to become a ldquoharder target when he was hit in the back by a bullet and fell to the ground.Father Hugh Mullan crawled to him, waving a white cloth, and offered to administer the Last Rites.ldquoHe said lsquoIrsquoll anoint yoursquo, I said lsquoFather, I am not going to diersquo, he said lsquoIrsquoll anoint you, it will strengthen yoursquo, Mr Clarke told the inquest.The  victims of the Ballymurphy Massacre He said that Fr Mullan told him he was going to call an ambulance for him, but after just a few steps he was struck by a bullet and fell to the ground where he was hit with a second bullet.Another man, Frank Quinn, , was also shot dead.He said he and his brother Gerald later ldquoslid over to longer grass close to Finlayrsquos Factory and lay for hours before they felt safe to move.ldquoWe were trapped there until it was dark enough to get out, he added.Mr Clarke said he believes he was shot by soldiers who were at ground level on Springfield Park, and that they were members of the Parachute Regiment, based on his wound that he described as ldquohorizontal.He told the inquest he has had  years of ldquoliving this, and holds himself responsible for the deaths of the two men.ldquoTwo people lost their lives coming to help me while I was trying to help those who could not help themselves, he said.ldquoThatrsquos a very heavy burden to have.He also told the inquest that he gave a statement about Fr Mullanrsquos death to a police sergeant at the Henry Taggart base. That statement has not been traced.When that was put to him, he responded: ldquoI wouldnrsquot be surprised to tell you the truth, before adding ldquocover up when asked why.Mr Clarke said internment destroyed his street.ldquoSpringfield Park was a blueprint for Northern Ireland, Catholics and Protestants living in harmony, he said.ldquoOne night destroyed it. Internment.Earlier, the inquest heard another man who had been in the field during the shootings said he saw no gunmen in the area that evening other than three men he believed were soldiers, one of whom was armed with a rle.ldquoNo one who was on that field had any weapons, no one was a threat to anyone, and thatrsquos the Godrsquos honest truth, Francis Corr told the inquest.The inquest continues.Speaking outside court Mr Clarke said he feels relieved having given evidence to the inquest.ldquoI feel responsible for those who lost their lives coming to help me because I was only helping other people, I still feel responsible, he said.ldquoI feel relieved up to a point because I think I could have done more, itrsquos a terrible thing to have on your conscience these  years, two people died helping you.ldquoI live with that every day..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Belfast street was a blueprint for N Ireland, Ballymurphy inquest told

title: pms-plan-to-rush-brexit-ratification-through-parliament-by-march-29
story: Theresa May has set out plans to short circuit parliamentary rules in order to get a Brexit deal ratied in time for the UK to leave the EU on March .The Prime Minister told MPs that she would enable the House of Commons to lt a requirement for a -day delay before any vote to approve an international treaty.But Labour pledged to oppose the move, accusing the Government of showing ldquocontempt for our democracy.The announcement came as Mrs May urged MPs to ldquohold their nerve and support her efforts to secure a withdrawal deal which will deliver Brexit on time.In a statement updating the Commons on progress in talks, Mrs May acknowledged she would need ldquosome time to seek legally-binding changes from the EU to the controversial backstop for the Irish border.She confirmed that she will table an amendable motion for debate on Thursday, seeking the Housersquos continued support for her to demand ldquoalternative arrangements to keep the border open after Brexit.And she pledged toon February  with a further statement ndash triggering another debate and votes the following day ndashshe has not secured a deal by that date.If a deal is agreed, MPs will have a second ldquomeaningful vote, like the one in January which saw Mrs Mayrsquos original plan rejected by a record-breaking  votes.The February  votes are expected to come shortly after Mrs Mayrsquos planned meeting with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, at which changes or additions to the Withdrawal Agreement could be agreed.With  days to go, former attorney general Dominic Grieve warned that time was running perilously short for ratication of any deal under the terms of the Constitutional Reform and Governance Act.The Act, passed by Gordon Brownrsquos administration in , requires  sitting days before the ratication of any international treaty.Dominic Grieve demanded to know how the PM could get her Brexit ratication bill through without extending the March  deadline But Mrs May responded: ldquoIn most circumstances, that period may be important in order for this House to have an opportunity to study that agreement.ldquoBut of course, in this instance MPs will already have debated and approved the agreement as part of the meaningful vote.ldquoSo while we will follow normal procedurewe can, where there is insufficient time remaining following a successful meaningful vote, we will make provision in the Withdrawal Agreement Bill ndash with Parliamentrsquos consent ndash to ensure that we are able to raty on time to guarantee our exit in an orderly way.PA GraphicsLabour Brexit spokesman Paul Blomfield said:ldquoThis plan shows contempt for our democracy.ldquoThe Government is trying to avoid proper scrutiny and run down the clock in order to force through its bad Brexit deal.ldquoLabour will oppose this change, which would deny Parliament full scrutiny.And Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran, a supporter of the Best for Britain campaign for a second referendum, said:ldquoMay will stop at nothing to crowbar through her botched Brexit deal eventhat means ripping up the statute book and subverting parliamentary scrutiny and process.ldquoThis cynical and undemocratic move must not be allowed to happen.But the PMrsquos official spokesman pointed out that by the time the -day period to consider the Brexit treaty kicked in, MPs would already have passed judgment on it in the ldquomeaningful vote and the Withdrawal Agreement Bill.ldquoItrsquos very hard to see a circumstance where having voted to pass the deal and then voted to enshrine its provisions in law, Parliament could hold up our exit in order to allow MPs to read the treaty, said the spokesman.The process would be accelerated by a clause in the Withdrawal Agreement Bill itself, which would disapply the terms of the  Act in this case, he said.Mrs May sidestepped demands from several MPs to spell out whether she would ask the EU for an extension to the two-year Brexit negotiation process or allow the UK to crash out without a dealshe hit the March  deadline with no agreement.In stormy exchanges in the Commons, the SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford risked being thrown out of the chamber after shouting ldquoliar at the PM.And Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn suggested the PM was ldquorunning down the clock on Brexit in the hope that MPs will be ldquoblackmailed by the fear of a no-deal outcome into supporting ldquoa deeply flawed deal.ldquoThis is an irresponsible act, said Mr Corbyn.ldquoShe is playing for time and membership, a close alignment with the single market and matching EU workplace and environmental protections.Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn listens to the PMrsquos statement But Mrs May insisted that she was listening to voices outside the Government, adding that ministers would have further talks with Labour on Wednesday on its list of five demandsit is to support a deal.She was heckled as she denied running down the clock, telling Mr Corbyn that she ldquowanted to have this sorted before Christmas.Labour MPs loudly retorted that she had pulled a ldquomeaningful vote in December because of fears title: letter wild salmon migration
story: It was recently reported that the Scottish Gamekeepers Associationis calling for a ban on fish farms being built on wild salmon migration routes.The SGA fishing group believe careful positioning of proposed farms and re-siting problem pens could stop wild stocks being infested with parasites‎.Crown Estate Scotland, under the Freedom of InformationAct ‎, confirmed MOWI, formerly known as Marine Harvest, has a lease option agreement to a third site in the Kilbrannan Sound.This is a short term conditional agreement, for a secure and exclusive interest, that can be exercised for a full lease once all necessary consents # including planning permission and the marine licence have been secured.With the planned expansion, by an increase of  per cent, of the two existing MOWI sites, at Carradale and a third site at Cour Point, Kilbrannan Sound will be home to the single largest concentration of fish farm pens and salmon biomass in Europe.The SGA believe sea lice outbreaks from salmon farms contribute to the collapse of wild salmon stocks.A spokesperson said: #While a healthy salmon can survive with a burden of sealice, the high number of lice found in captive areas can lead to weakness and death.#Does Argyll and Bute Council and the Scottish Government acknowledge both the impact of sea lice and the subsequent use of chemicals, presently being felt in the Kilbrannan Sound An impact not only on wild salmon and sea trout stocks also our very localised lobster, crab and prawn fishing industry In past decades Kilbrannan Sound would have been described as a super highway for migrating wild salmon.Legislation in Norway, and recently British Colombia, does not permit the siting of fish farms on recognised wild salmon migration routes.Is it the local authority and national government#s intention to down grade the Sound, once plentul in fish and crustaceans alike, to that of a backwater trickle Tommy Macpherson,Saddell.

title: letter kintyre needs a modern connectivity system
story: The Scottish Government is seeking views on the proposed future Glasgow to Campbeltown air service prior to it being retendered.I have discussed this specic issue with friends and we have concerns about the current unreliable ferry, air services and road link.We believe we should receive at the very least the same air service as provided to the island of Islay.We have the following thoughts on improvements to encourage new businesses to locate here and to promote tourism.We would like a larger Saab  or equivalent aircraft that can land in more adverse weather conditions # we understand the economies of scale and suggest a service that can fly to Campbeltown and then on to Islay, back to Campbeltown and ing to Glasgow, or vice versa.We would like the reinstatement of the radar system to assist landings in adverse weather conditions.As there is a separate service between Islay and Edinburgh we suggest that Campbeltown should be included as we also have key tourist attractions such as distilleries and three fantastic -hole golf courses and high-standard accommodation.We would like to see the service continue with a timetable with low ticket prices to allow the full day in Glasgow for NHS appointments, business and shopping trips and the reinstatement of seven days a week flights to enhance business and tourism.In addition, we want national advertising campaigns inclusive of timetables to promote the area for increased passenger numbers, including weekend breaks.These aspirations are very much in keeping with the council’s Community Plan Single Outcome Agreement   in particular relating to National Policy Priorities i.e. economic recovery, growth and employment.We are also very much aware of organisations which have worked hard to promote the long-term outcomes in the Community Plan.The communities of Kintyre need a modern connectivity system, fit for purpose,this area is to have any credibility in the big wide world.Decent flight connections to the major hubs of Glasgow and Edinburgh would be a start.I have confirmed the Scottish Government is collecting views andyou would like to help improve our air service and have additional comments or suggestions, I urge you to email them to: Michael.Bratcher@transport. gov.scotAndrew Hemmings,

title: thought for the week february 1 2019
story: February  marks the midpoint of winter, half way between the shortest day and the spring equinox.For Christians it has a particularly special meaning as it was  days after the birth of Jesus and the day when, according to Jewish custom, his grateful parents took him to the temple to give thanks to God.We believe that Jesus is the light of the world who will guide us through our own dark times.Many customs have grown around Candlemas and one of the most interesting came from Scotland.In the olden days, Candlemas was the day when children brought candles to school so that the classrooms would have light on dull days.As time went on, gas lighting took over from candlelight and the children brought money to school with which the teacher was supposed to buy sweets for the children.The child who brought in the most money was declared Candlemas King or Queen and they ruled for six weeks.They had the power to make one whole afternoon a week a playtime and to excuse anyone they wished from any form of punishment.I don#t think this will catch on in Argyll!I think it is a lovely custom to take a child to church or temple for a blessing and to give thanks to God for their birth.I have the privilege of being chaplain to two primary schools and while I cannot take the children physically to church or temple, I take each one of them to God every day in my prayers to give thanks for them and ask God#s blessing upon them.

title: hscps financial position
story: The integrated joint boardwhich runs the partnership was told recently that while health and social care finances are #not good,# steps are being taken to improve matters.A £.m overspend is currently being forecast by the HSCP, which may rise as high as £.m depending on a service level agreement with NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde .Savings have been slow to the point where only  per cent of the target is set to be delivered in the current financial year – but some progress is felt to be getting made.Argyll and Bute Councillor Gary Mulvaney, a member of the IJB, praised the work of the authority’s head of finance, Kirsty Flanagan, who is currently in the same position for the HSCP on an interim basis.He said: #This paper went to the quality and financial board. The board has certainly had a thorough look through it and as a matter of record we should appreciate it.#One thing that has caused frustration at previous meetings has been the dficulty in reading some of the financial papers.#This doesn’t change the overall picture, which is not a good one, but when you see it like this, it is easier.#The key things I take out will be the grip and control actions that the board are approving today.#As Kirsty says, this is not just a one-week wonder – this is a continuous process to help improve the financial position.#Although the outlook is not good there is a positive in that we have a better transparency and now that we have the grip and control we can look to move forward and see what dference it makes.#At the meeting, Ms Flanagan explained why an overspend is projected when the HSCP is currently operating at an underspend of just more than £,.The HSCP, run jointly by the council and NHS Highland, may face even further financial woean agreement is not reached with NHSGGC.Ms Flanagan said: #The finances within the dferent organisations are managed dferently. There is no right or wrong approach.#There has been a lower than budgeted demand for care home services. The focus of attention needs to be on the full year position, so reporting an overspend of £.m is a deterioration on where we were at our November meeting.#The main reason for this is dficulty in delivering over £m worth of savings. There also remains a risk to the out turn in the SLA with NHSGGC.#The board made the decision at the November meeting to reject the agreement and the overspend has been adjusted to reflect this.#If this position is not accepted by NHSGGC, the overspend could increase by up to £.m.#Cllr Mulvaney then proposed that a repayment plan from the HSCP to the council is deferred by a year.This involves the authority being repaid any loss made by the HSCP over a three-year period, with £, due in the first financial year, £, in the second financial year, and the balance in year three.Ms Flanagan said: #We should seek clarication but I think that would be a reasonable request.#It was also advised that a job description has been finalised for a permanent head of finance with the HSCP and should be advertised soon.

title: bus fare payments to go contactless
story: Nearly half a million pounds has been awarded in the first round of the fund to help firms cope with the costs of upgrading ticket machines to accept contactless bank payments.The cash has been awarded from the Scottish Government and European Regional Development Fund.It is estimated to provide a contactless payment solution to potentially . million fare paying journeys right across Scotland.The fund builds on the successful rollout of contactless payment by the country’s largest operators and responds to feedback from smaller operators around the financial barriers to upgrading.The Scottish Government’s vision is that all journeys on Scotland’s public transport networks can be made using some form of smart ticketing or payment by spring .Commenting on the first awards, cabinet secretary for transport, Michael Matheson said: #Contactless payments make it easier to access travel in Scotland and I am delighted we have been able to support up to  smaller operators in making the transition to this convenient payment solution.#This government is committed to supporting the industry and also people right across the country who choose to travel by bus.#By helping smaller operators with the financial costs of upgrading to contactless payment, customers will benefit from quicker and easier transactions, whether by card or by mobile phone.#A second round of the fund hasl opened and we are widening this fund out to all operators, so that even more organisations can take advantage of the support on offer.#Keith Shand, Assistant Operations Manager at Garelochhead Mini Bus and Coaches, said: #Modern day society expects to board a bus and not have to carry the correct change.#Feedback from our customers shows  per cent have indicated they would use contactless payments on our buses and we’re delighted that we will now be able to deliver this service.#The Courier emailed West Coast Motors for a comment but no-one responded.

NO_cfilesTWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGODoc#s a lesaverThe swt and decisive actions of a Carradale doctor # #far beyond# the call of duty # have saved the le of a villager.Dr Robert Abernethy masterminded a mercy dash from the village to Campbeltown and finally to Glasgow to save businessman Jerry Singal.A fortnight ago, Mr Singal # who runs Carradale#s Glen Restaurant # felt unwell, and contacted the doctor.He was immediately given antibiotics. Then when Dr Abernethy left surgery, he continued to call on the patient, right up until .pm at night.It was at this time that the doctor decided to drive Mr Singal to Campbeltown Hospital.And finally, at am, Dr Abernethy insisted that his patient be taken by air ambulance to Glasgow.It was here that surgeons performed a tracheotomy on Mr Singal, an incision made when the air passage has been blocked # his throat had #swelled like a balloon#.The surgeons told Mr Singal thatit hadn#t been for the actions of the local doctor, he would have been dead.#This man saved my le, it#s as simple as that,# Jerry said this week. #His dedication to this village is out of this world.#FIFTY YEARS AGOThe oldest # and the championAlthough Kintyre Agricultural Society#s annual ploughing match was postponed on Saturday because of the state of the ground, the Islay Ploughing Society went ahead with its competition.The T Jarret Trophy for the best ploughed lot on the field was won by Alex Campbell, Woodend Cottages, Ballygrant, who was the oldest competitor.The competition was held on Islay House Home Farm, by courtesy of Lord Margadale of Islay.The judge was Mr Ewan McPherson of Dalrannoch, Barcaldine, and the prizes were presented by Mrs Donald McGillivray.They were thanked by the secretary, Mr Donald McIntyre, Ballygrant, as were the ladies who did the catering , the donors of the prizes, and all who had helped to make the match a success.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOA firm answerSober men will heartily approve the firm reply which the government promptly dispatched to the threatening ultimatum which the strikers on the Clyde transmitted through the Lord Provost of Glasgow.The Clyde is the most notorious centre of operations of the extreme revolutionary section of organised Labour.The demands that are now made are both in the method of making them and in their character of violation not only of the established methods of industrial bargaining, but of the first principles of civil order.The strike is not authorised by the responsible executive of the union concerned.And the ultimatum of the strikers to the government was not an appeal for arbitration in the accepted sense but a demand that the government should forthwith champion the case of the strikers and coerce the employers into unconditional surrender.This demand was accompanied by threats suggestive of the highwayman#s formula: #Your money or your le.#Now it is patent that the business of government, the commerce of the country, and the stability of the social fabric cannot be conducted and sustainedthere is any shilly shallying with such reckless minorities as those responsible for such an ultimatum as this.

title: down memory lane february 8 2019
story: That year NASA was formed as the two Cold War superpowers, America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics , vied for off world power and raced to put a man in space.Angus MacVicar, a Courier editor in the s, was a novelist determined that Scotland would have a starring role.Last week, while on holiday, a Courier reporter spotted MacVicar#s  work in the eclectic collection of a Great Malvern, Worcestershire second-hand bookshop.The cover features a dish for communicating with a geostationery satellite, such as the first Telstar, launched in , and a rocket launching pad.The two are connected by a road with an uncanny resemblance to the track leading to the Mull lighthouse.Angus, who eventually bought a property in Southend and lived to , before passing away in , belonged to a North Uist family whose history can be traced back  years.The flyleaf to the book states he became a #hard working newspaperman#   at the Courier in , after graduating from Glasgow University and, when the editor Alec MacLeod, had a serious ilness, in  stepped up to the hot seat.Not content with writing all day, Angus, in the words of another former Courier reporter, Freddy Gillies: #burned the midnight oil,# to write the first of  novels # The Purple Rock, published in  by Stanley Paul.He left to become a full-time author and broadcaster although the Second World War intervened.Angus took part in three assault landings # Madagascar, Sicily and Italy and was mentioned in dispatches for his part in the break-out at Anzio.Satellite , costing three shillings and six pence, was published  years before Paul McCartney came to Kintyre and tells the tale of radio and television singing star, Tony Thomson, aged  and his younger brother Jake.They are shipwrecked on a remote Hebridean island, find a government research station and are detained by the inhabitants.Eventually some of the mystery is unravelled  when they learn Britain is about to launch its seventh satellite, built to circle the moon andwith the first photographs of its dark side.Angus#s first volume of autobiography, Salt In My Porridge, subtitled Confession#s of a Minister#s son, was published in  and reprinted five times.It was first issued in paperback in  and currently changes hands for between . pence and £..Graeme Baird at the Old Bookshelf in Cross Street said that Angus# books are in great demand.The front cover of Satellite  features a tarred road which looks remarkably similar to the Mull lighthouse track. you could hear a pin drop during Cha and Annmarie#s Gaelic duets.More than  people attended the event which is organised and run by Campbeltown Community Council , and more than half won a prize in the free raffle, with shops, hotels and pubs making donations.The afternoon#s MC, Kay Johnston, was thanked for keeping things running smoothly by CCC chairman Alan Baker, who presented her with a bunch of flowers.Former CCC member Cathy Duncan, who has helped organise the event for the last five or six years, was finally able to sit back, relax and enjoy the afternoon, as current members dished out tea, coffee and light bites supplied by Argyll Bakeries.Volunteers from Campbeltown Sea Cadets also helped to serve at the event.Mr Baker thanked everyone who had helped for making the afternoon #a great success#.Rhuvaal#s Arran McAllister and his uncle Alex McAllister on stage. _cseniorsCathy Duncan, third left, enjoyed the concert with friends. _cseniorsGillian MacIntyre joined her granny, Violet Dixon, who moved to Campbeltown from Rothesay last year, at the event. _cseniorsSome of the Campbeltown Community Council members who organised and ran the event. _cseniorsAnnmarie and Cha McLean sang a range of Gaelic songs. _cseniorsSea cadets Elyce Walker, James Ives, Joseph Davies, APO Greg Walker, Beth MacPherson and Isaac Morbey helped. _cseniorsLadies enjoying the concert. _cseniorsAlan Baker thanked everyone who contributed after presenting Kay Johnston with a bunch of flowers. _cseniorsMore than  people attended the concert. _cseniors

title: the sinopia quartet a review by david mcewan
story: The truthfulness of this was proved at the recent Kintyre Music Club concert last Friday.The Sinopia Quartet # two violins, viola and cello # delighted its audience with the works of just three composers – Bartók, Borodin and Dvořák.Bartók was a Hungarian who was a keen collector of folk melodies. The astringent harmonies, for which he was famous, underpinned six short Romanian folk dances with great effect.This piece was followed by Borodin’s famous nd Quartet.The melody forming part of the slow movement was used in the famous  musical Kismet.Borodin, a Russian, was a doctor and chemist by profession and composed music in his spare time. The second quartet revealed his total mastery of composition.After the interval the audience was treated to Dvořák’s #American# quartet. This was a piece bursting with fine tunes and boundless energy.With the players providing helpful information about the pieces, this concert was felt to be one of the best of the season.It proved the point that careful programme-planning incorporating plenty of good tunes usually sends everyone away happy.The players hands and arms are a blur as they play Bartók#s fast dance Maruntelul. _cSinopia_Kintyre_Music_ClubLorne and Lowland Old Church Hall was quite warm and Sinopia players had to tune-up regularly. _cSinopia_Tune_up

title: plans-to-build-houses-near-to-prestonpans-railway-station
story: LAR Housing Trust is aiming to create the new properties, which could be in place by spring next year, in a similar style to their recently-completed development in nearby Cockenzie.The development, which is being considered by East Lothian Council, would be created on the site of the former Lothian Coated Fabrics building and next to the eastbound  at the neighbouring railway station.LAR Housing Trust, which is an affordable housing provider, plans to create affordable housing on the site, which it will operate as  per cent affordable mid-market rent.Plans with the local authorityrsquos planning department note that the scheme would be ldquosimilar to the  flats at the Boatyard, Cockenzie Harbour.Dunfermline-based LAR Housing Trust said that the existing development had ldquoproven to be successful and well received by East Lothian Council, the local community and new residents.The design and access statement, which makes up part of the new planning application for the Prestonpans proposal, reads: ldquoThe Cockenzie Harbour site required high-quality design with traditional features and local character, linking into the surrounding area and conservation area.ldquoThese details fit equally well at this site in Prestonpans, bringing character in keeping with the traditional features of the railway station and adjacent housing.Nineteen of the flats, which would be based on the eastern side of the site, would have two bedrooms, with the remaining three as single-bedroom properties.Each of the four houses, which would be on the western side of the site, would have three bedrooms.Brian Weddell, chairman of Prestonpans Community Council, was aware of the proposals, which had yet to be discussed by the group.He said some concerns had already been raised regarding the size of the plot and the number of properties being proposed.However, he stressed that there was ldquoa crying need for affordable and social housing in the area, with the community council to discuss the proposals at a future meeting.Buildings on the site were demolished in , with the northern section transformed into a Co-op Foodstore and other units, including Links Veterinary Group.

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: tranent-teenager-recovering-well-after-horror-skiing-accident
story: An air ambulance brought Nicholas Guest back from Sion on Monday, with the teenager now in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Older sister Lizzy was delighted her brother was one step closer to being able to come home.She told the Courier: ldquoHe is a lot happier for being back in Scotland. There is a big change in his presentation.ldquoWe are all glad he is back and just along the road now instead of travelling hundreds of miles.Nicholas, , of Tranentrsquos Lawson Way, was placed in a coma following an accident while skiing in the resort of Saas-Fee, near the Italian border, earlier this month.The teenager bumped his head on the ground after going over a jump and underwent surgery, with doctors monitoring his condition.On Monday evening, he arrived back in Scotland and Lizzy, who lives in Haddington, said: ldquoHe is improving little bits all the time.ldquoHe has progressed quite a lot in the last two weeks considering how severe his injuries were.ldquoHe is awake for longer and he speaks a little bit more. He still has issues with his mobility but has been referred onto eye specialists, speech and language, and physiotherapy. He struggles on focusing his eyes a bit.ldquoBeing back in Scotland has made a massive dference just in terms of his mental health.ldquoAs well as his physical health improving, we are trying to encourage him to do as much as he can and we are trying to stimulate him to the maximum and get him recovering quicker.Nicholas plays rugby for Preston Lodge RFCrsquos under-s and was visited by a group from the rugby team in the hospital.A GoFundMe page was set up by Lizzyrsquos fianceacute, Daniel Hunter, to help cover the costs of the family going to visit Nicholas in Switzerland.An initial goal of pound, was quickly surpassed, with more than pound, now collected as the community rallies round.Lizzy said: ldquoWe are pretty amazed.ldquoIrsquom shocked, to be honest obviously we changed the goal when we realised quite a lot of people had donated.ldquoWe thought maybe people would help cover the expenses and it has been incredible.ldquoThat was really helpful and Nicholas appreciates it as well.ldquoIt has been great ndash even people we donrsquot know, friends of friends, that want to help. We donrsquot even know who they are and we are just really grateful they want to help us.Nicholas, who is in S at Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, faces a y recovery and rehabilitation period. It remains unclear when he will be able tohome, although Lizzy said her brother wanted to be home within three months.She added: ldquoNow we are going to be focusing on being there for Nicholas.ldquoWe have got our daily lives and jobs to go to but as a family we are all within a reasonable distance.ldquoWe can co-ordinate ourselves to be there at dferent times so he has always got someone with him.Lizzy and Nicholasrsquo mum Marian added: ldquoA great thank you to all who have supported us over the last couple of weeks and those who continue to do so. Nicholas knows about the support and it has had a huge impact on his recovery and wersquore very grateful for this.ldquoI also want to express thanks to all who help and support our family.ldquoThanks to the excellent staff at the Swiss hospital, air ambulance team, and staff at the Western General.To help support Nicholas, go to gofundme support-for-nicolas

title: musselburgh-racecourse-abandons-cheltenham-trials-weekend
story: The racecourses premier jumps weekend fixture had been set to take place this Saturday and Sunday but sub-zero temperatures have put paid to the event, it was announced today.**The @bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials Weekend has been ABANDONED**Unfortunately, due to a frozen track  low temperatures this weekendrsquos Scottish Cheltenham Trials Racemeeting has been abandoned.We are looking to reschedule  more information will follow. pic alVcaiijHarriet Graham, clerk of the course, said: ldquoVery sadly we have had to abandon our Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend because of frozen ground.ldquoWe have tried really hard to get this meeting on, putting fleeces on the whole course, but unfortunately with temperatures as low as - last night and the night before, the frost has got underneath the fleece and there is no prospect of temperatures rising enough over the next few days for us to get racing on Saturday or Sunday.ldquoIt is such a great shame as we had a very exciting weekend ahead of us, but we just canrsquot beat the weather I am afraid.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, added: ldquoMusselburgh will seek the opportunity to stage an extra fixture which will meet the needs of horses that would otherwise have raced at our bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend.Refunds will be made available and the racecourse will be in contact with all race-goers who have purchased advance admission tickets.For more information, visit the racecourse website and social media feeds.

title: big-backlog-of-500-street-lights-needing-fixed-in-east-lothian
story: Complaints about lights are logged on an interactive map on East Lothian Councilrsquos website, which shows that some were reported as not working as far back as October last year, with the fault still classed as ldquounveried.A senior officer at East Lothian Council confirmed the backlog as he responded to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside a school.He said that budget cuts had ldquorun down our establishment and the council was unable to recruit enough electricians because it could not compete with private sector salaries.In an email, the senior lighting officer said: ldquoThe council currently has a backlog of some  lighting faults. We are also suffering from a shortage of staff to address the issue.ldquoBudget cuts have run down the establishment and further recruitment has proved unsuccessful, with electricians outwith local government enjoying much higher levels of remuneration than we can offer.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the council administrationrsquos spokesperson for the environment, insisted that the number of faults equated to ldquoless than three per cent of the , lights the local authority operated in the county.And he said that more than half the lights in East Lothian had been converted to LED, requiring far less maintenance.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoIn the meantime, we are continuing to inspect reported faults as quickly as possible and, where a fault is a matter for ScottishPower, we are making sure this is dealt with as soon as possible.ldquoWhere repairs are our responsibility, we have used electrical contractors to assist with repairing lighting faults and we plan to use this resource again when the need arises.Mr Hampshire added that some lights in new housing developments remained the responsibility of developers until they were transferred to the council.The senior officer was responding to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside Dunbar Primary Schoolrsquos John Muir campus. He confirmed that the council had used contractors in the past but said: ldquoThe high costs involved mean any long-term engagement is unsustainable.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoIn relation to recruitment, East Lothian Council is experiencing the same challenges as other local authorities are as a result of UK growth and we are seeking to mitigate this impact.Among the street lights currently out of action are some at Robertson Drive and Lindores Drive in Tranent due to a faulty cable, with ScottishPower stating work is due to be carried out late next month.Check your street lights on the local authorityrsquos interactive map here.

title: retiring-golf-club-starter-recalls-meeting-neil-armstrong-and-movie-stars
