title: Iain Macwhirter  After making demands she couldn t accept  Corbyn has made Theresa May an offer she can   t refuse
story: Last week, Corbyn made a remarkable overture to the Prime Minister. He effectively dropped his opposition to her Withdrawal Agreement, which Labour had repeatedly condemned as the ldquoworst of all worlds. The Labour leaderrsquos letter still calls for a customs union, regulatory alignment on trade and guarantees on workers rights and security cooperation. But, crucially, Labour is no longer holding to the ldquosix tests, and insisting a Brexit deal should deliver ldquoexactly the same benefits as being in the single market.Labour has even dropped its opposition to the Irish backstop, which Mr Corbyn condemned, as recently as December, for leaving Britain ldquoin an indefinite halfway house with no say on its future. The explanatory note that Labour circulated after the leaderrsquos letter to May is quite clear. ldquoAny withdrawal agreement," it says, ldquowill need to include a backstop." Labour is also hinting at further compromises in ldquonegotiations.Hitherto, Labourrsquos policy has been to make demands May could never accept now they are trying to make her an offer she canrsquot refuse.So at last, after months of there being nothing much new to say about Brexit, suddenly we have what looks like a breakthrough, a historic compromise. Of course, you canrsquot overestimate the ability of political leaders to look a gt horse in the mouth. Theresa May may be so wedded to being a ldquobloody dficult womanthat she may find a way to avoid accepting Labourrsquos free hooved mammal. But the deal is there to be made.Senior Tories like Sir Oliver Letwin have welcomed the Labour offer, seeing it as a step towards a Norway-style agreement, even though it isnrsquot. Labourrsquos plan is much closer to Turkey, which is also in a customs union and accepts regulatory alignment. Brussels likes Corbyns proposals too, as a way out of hard Brexit ldquohell.Ive argued that the logic of Labourrsquos position was always to back something resembling Theresa Mayrsquos deal with the EU. It corresponds to Labourrsquos manesto commitments to leaving the EU, including the single market, and ending free movement while seeking frictionless trade. Mrs May has always supported regulatory alignment, since the ldquocommon rule book in her Chequers plan. And the backstop, remember, involves the UK remaining in the customs union until there is a future comprehensive trade deal.In what could almost have been a coordinated intervention last week, Mrs May restated in Dublin her determination to prevent a hard border in Ireland. This put the wind up the DUP, since they fear that the border might now move to the Irish Sea.It didnrsquot appeal to the hardline Brexiteers in her own party either, who are adamant that no deal is better than her bad deal. They thought it had been killed off by last monthrsquos record-breaking Commons defeat ndash but it may now live again with Labourrsquos backing.They canrsquot admit it, of course, but May and Corbyn are now speaking broadly the same language. The customs union, regulatory alignment, rights and protections etc are all matters to do with the future trade relationship with the EU, not the Withdrawal Agreement. It covers only money, citizenship and the Good Friday Agreement.The trading relationship can only be negotiated after Brexit. It is to be hammered out within the up to four years of the transition period, during which the UK remains in the single market and the customs union.Onlythere is no agreement does the backstop comes into play, and that really just extends the transition period indefinitely. May has said she will get assurances that the backstop will be time-limited, but she canrsquot get that from the European Union. If it was limited, it would no longer be a backstop.What hard Brexiteers really fear is that the transition period might lead to a soft Brexit, not a clean break ndash and they are right. What we know is that MPs will block any no-deal Brexit. Hardliners face a choice of May Corbyn or no Brexit at all.To secure a Commons majority without them, Mrs May could promise legislation to keep Britain in regulatory alignment with the customs union until a new trade deal is finalised ndash one which delivers the same benefits. This is anyway implicit in her promises to keep trade ldquofrictionless. Indeed, remaining in a customs union is the only way of achieving this. Up to now, she hasnrsquot been able to say this openly for fear of a rebellion by her hardline backbenchers, led by Jacob Rees-Mogg. They want a managed no-deal now, or in four years, under the so-called ldquoMalthouse Plan.Butshe has an ounce of political sense, May will now face them down and pivot to Labourrsquos softish Brexit. Labourrsquos demand that she put the customs union in primary legislation can be finessed, because the trade negotiations canrsquot happen until after Brexit. She doesnrsquot even need to ensure that Labour votes with her. Labour could abstain in the meaningful vote and achieve essentially the same result. The DUP would accept the customs union as a guarantee against a backstop or an east west hard border.Jeremy Corbyn could explain Labourrsquos abstention, which will be attacked by Vote Leave MPs andleader writers, by saying, as his spokespeople did last week: that the top priority ldquofor the nation is to avoid a no-deal. Corbynite commentators can be relied upon to condemn any Labour MPs who continue to vote against Mayrsquos deal as traitors. Unreconstructed Blairites, voting with the hated Moggists to force a no-deal disaster.Corbynrsquos letter made no reference to a Peoples Vote. Remainers in the Labour Party realise where all this is heading, which is why a number, like former shadow cabinet figures like Owen Smith, and Clive Lewis, have threatened to leave the party. That could become part of the script.Corbyn has used the Brexit issue to smoke out Blairite Remainers like Chuka Umunna, and the Jewish MP, Luciana Berger, in order to portray them as disloyal splitters.Of course, ordinary members of the Labour Party will be mightily confused. Many of them still think Labour is committed to a referendum. It still could come to that, of course,May doesnrsquot seize this opportunity.I still harbour vague hopes that A could be revoked, but Irsquom afraid that pro-Europeans are on the wrong side of history right now. The country is destined to leave the EU, because letrsquos face it, Labour under Jeremy Corbyn is and has always been a pro-Brexit party.And after Brexit Day  Well, get ready for Groundhog Day  as negotiations over the future EU trade deal begin all over again.

title: call-to-cash-in-on-the-harry-potter-railway
story: Famed for its spellbinding scenery and the iconic Glenfinnan viaduct, the West Highland Railway has become an international tourist attraction after doubling for the route taken by the Hogwarts Express in the film adaptation of JK Rowlings novels.Now Scotrail is being urged to cash in on the soaring numbers of passengers on the line, which runs from Glasgow to Fort William and onto Mallaig, by putting on extra services and providing a better experience for tourists.And a fresh injection of funds could also be magic for those travelling the A by easing congestion on the road to the Isles.Fresh figures published by the Office of Rail Regulation have revealed that the number of people travelling on the "Harry Potter" railway has doubled in the past decade, while hundreds are travelling to the countryside nearby to watch the train as it crosses the bridge.And the line - previously been hailed as one of the most scenic in the world - continues to be a runaway success, with the latest statistics show that the number of passengers passing through Fort William station growing by ,between  and last year.:Police issue warning to viaduct touristsThe numbers arriving at Glenfinnan station follow a similar track, rising by almost , while those reaching Mallaig are up by , or  per cent.Annual passenger numbers have increased by almost , passengers across the area, with growth at other towns such as Aviemore, Dingwall and Kyle of Lochalsh also appearing in the figures.Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch constituency, believes that now is the time to capitalise on the popularity of the enchanting route.She said: ldquoItrsquos fantastic to see more people choosing to go on the lsquoHarry Potter linersquo and experience the fantastic scenery at the Glenfinnan viaduct, as well as the breath-taking views from Fort William to Mallaig generally.ldquoUltimately, I would like to see more people using public transport instead of driving as it reduces congestion and its good for the environment. That means that public transport needs to be reliable, comfortable and regular.ldquoI would like to see ScotRail invest more signicantly on this line, and capitalise on the clear growth in tourism the area is experiencing. Strategically, especially given the frequent delays with Fort William traffic in the peak summer months, it makes sense to get more people off of the road and onto trains.Kate Forbes,MSPThe West Highland Railway is  miles long and runs by Loch Long, Loch Lomond and Loch Eil, passing the silver sands of Morar.Ms Forbes added: ldquoSeeing passengers up by over , in Fort William and also by nearly , in Mallaig is absolutely brilliant.:From Bond to the BFG - on the Scottish film set trailldquoFor a relatively small fishing village like Mallaig where parking is under pressure, that is a colossal increase and I hope that local shops and businesses have felt the benefit of the rise in visitors.ldquoIf demand continues to grow, ScotRail and Network Rail should invest more so that visitors and locals alike can enjoy the beauty of the West Highlands.Filming of s Harry Potter and the Chambers of Secrets and Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, released in , took place at Glenfinnan. In real-le, the Express is the Jacobite steam train.The viaduct is the largest concrete railway bridge in Scotland and was opened in . It crosses the River Finnan at a height of  feet and overlooks Loch Shiel and the Glenfinnan Monument to the Jacobite rebellion of .More than , visitors flocking to Glenfinnan Station in -, and ScotRail has announced it will build a new footpath to help handle the volume of people.Boy Wizard Harry Potter takes the train to school each yearMeanwhile, a walkway that crosses the hillside between the railway station and the viaduct will be upgraded to provide easier access to several new viewing areas, allowing tourists to capture the stunning scenery.:Potter fans boyfriend proposes aboard the Hogwarts Express.The project will be a working partnership between ScotRail, the West Highland Community Rail Partnership , Glenfinnan Station Museum, Glenfinnan Estate, Network Rail and Transport Scotland.It is hoped the work helps to increase the proportion of visitors arriving by public transport by improving the facilities available.ScotRail project manager Anouska Chisolm said: "The new footpath and viewing areas at the Glenfinnan Viaduct will be fantastic for tourism in the area and we hope it will encourage more visitors to travel here by rail instead of car."Its important that we continue to work with our key partners on how we can boost tourism and bring wider economic benefits along Scotlands most scenic railways."

title: business-diary-of-nicola-sturgeons-top-aide-records-gym-class-but-not-alex-salmond-meeting
story: Official logs show Liz Lloyd enjoyed an early morning fitness class on April , while a work catch-up meeting scheduled for later that afternoon was cancelled.But the diary, released under Freedom of Information, makes no mention of a meeting between Mr Salmond and Ms Sturgeon at the latterrsquos house in Glasgow that same day, despite Ms Lloyd also being present.:Calls for public inquiry into "unlawful" handling of sexual misconduct complaints against Alex SalmondIt was during this meeting that Mr Salmond first told his successor he was being investigated by the Scottish Government amid allegations of sexual harassment.A spokesman for the Scottish Tories said: ldquoPeople will certainly have questions to ask about the diary of a senior taxpayer-funded Scottish Government employee.ldquoThe SNP Government does not have to wait for the Holyrood investigation, and could clary exactly what this member of staff was doing on these days, and why.Entries in Ms Lloydrsquos business diary covering the dates of phone calls and meetings between Ms Sturgeon and Mr Salmond were released following an FoI request.It comes amid intense scrutiny of the contacts, during which Mr Salmond brought up a Government investigation into sexual harassment allegations against him.:Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond at war over poundk legal caseThe meetings are set to be probed by MSPs after questions were raised over Ms Sturgeonrsquos involvement and her initial decision not to report the contact. She insists it was not government business.It previously emerged Ms Lloyd helped set up the meeting on April . However, her business diary shows no record of it ndash but takes time to log a fitness ldquoboot camp at .am.Mr Salmond appeared in court last month charged with two attempted rapes, nine sexual assaults, two indecent assaults and one breach of the peace. He strongly denies any criminality.A Scottish Government spokeswoman said Ms Sturgeon had set out her position, and it would not be appropriate to comment further.

title: bid-underway-to-turn-scots-power-station-site-into-cruise-ship-port
story: Now a bid is underway to transform a landmark former power station into a new port to take advantage of the countryrsquos booming cruise liner business ndash and have a multi-million-pound impact on Scotlandrsquos food and drink exports in the process.:Isle of Arran is Scotlands first plastic-free communityFigures from trade body Cruise Scotland for last year show a . per cent year-on-year rise in passenger numbers to ,, with an .% increase in ships to .And experts say Scotland is now recognised as the second largest growth market globally for the cruise industry.Prestonpans Community Council is promoting the transformation of the former Cockenzie Power Station, which was decommissioned in March , into a new port.It is backed by transport consultant Roy Pedersen, who invented the road equivalent tarf, or RET, the new fare structure designed to ensure crossing water is no more expensive than driving the same distance.Mr Pedersen, who serves on the Scottish Governmentrsquos Expert Ferries Group, said the -acre Preston Links site, now owned by East Lothian Council, has a number of advantages that would make it a top spot for cruise ships, including a sheltered location with deep water close to shore, ready access to the main navigation fairway and no height restrictions.He also believes the port offers the potential for reinstating a Scotland-continent ferry link, estimating up to , jobs would be generated directly and indirectly from the whole project.He said: ldquoA further advantage of the new port is that once cruise ships can be berthed alongside, the port is strategically well placed as a cruise turn-around port, which means that the job-generating business of crew change and supplying vessels with food and other necessities presents a signicant economic opportunity.ldquoTypically, a , passenger cruise ship requires about pound million worth of supplies for one weekrsquos cruising, of which a substantial proportion is food and drink, thereby contributing to Scotlandrsquos food and drink exports.Calum Miller, a member of Prestonpans Community Council, said one of the factors driving the bid is the attraction of Edinburgh as a cruise ship ldquohoneypot destination. In a blog, he added that at the core of the problem are Victorian port facilities that canrsquot scale to handle the bigger cruise liners.He said: ldquoThese ships canrsquot limbo under the Forth bridges to visit Rosyth, nor squeeze into Leith docks. Instead, passengers are force-ferried on small tenders to South Queensferry or Newhaven harbour.Rob Mason, head of Cruise for Capital Cruising, Forth Portsrsquo cruise business, said, though: ldquoWe are extremely proud of our cruise business.ldquoWe are seeing our passenger numbers grow each year, through investment in our facilities and we continue to seek opportunities across the Forth to accommodate the increase in demand from larger cruise liners.The key feature of the proposed new port is a simple finger pier, with sufficientand depth alongside to accommodate the largest cruise ships and a berth for a cruise ferry to provide a nightly service to the continent.A similar finger pier at Tallinn, Estonia, was built for just pound million though a more extensive pier and related terminal land at Hatston near Kirkwall cost between poundm and poundm.:Highland port to undergo poundm revamp to welcome worlds biggest cruise shipsMr Miller said: ldquoWith a little dredging and investment, the biggest ships could soon be gliding alongside a more modern quay with professional facilities. This new terminal would have the capacity to act as a home port, increasing the inidual passenger spend in the Lothians to pound.Based on bookings, around , liners are heading for Scottish ports this year, with passenger numbers expected to be up by .% at more than ,.Mr Pederson added: ldquoIf handled skilfully, Scotland has the opportunity to reap huge economic benefit from a modern low carbon cruise and ferry port that will transform both our access to continental markets, but will create a world ferry and class cruise turn-around port that is so lacking at present.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoA port for cruise is one of a number of ideas that have been promoted for the site. Technical work would be required to determine viability including a port engineering study, an environmental assessment and an economic analysis.

title: letters-bias-has-now-become-part-of-the-ethos-of-the-bbcs-question-time
story: The "non-political" lists are frequently even more extreme in their views, particularly over Brexit, and far more aggressive in putting forward their view. That someone should be a member of the audience on dferent occasions should surprise no one, as the main concern of the producers is viewing figures, and these are boosted by having controversy, not by providing information.On the issue of bias, it is, sadly, there and seems part of the ethos of the programme. On Question Time a few days before the EU referendum, both David Dimbleby and Chris Grayling were out of their chairs to correct a lady who referred to "English values", pointing out that the said values were in reality "British". This political correctness did not long survive the vote, and not one on the  a few weeks later corrected an audience member who referred to "English industry and trade".Having watched the decline in standards over the past  months, I have decided not to waste my time watching Question Time. If I want to hear a reasoned and intelligent political discussion, I will ask a group of teenagers their opinion.T J Dowds,q Fleming Road, Cumbernauld.I NOTE with interest Mark Smiths article. I have thought for some time that Question Time has lost its way and that we no longer are presented with considered debate from reasonably informed members of the public. It seems to be a perpetual shouting joust from hand-picked members of the public. Last weeks episode was the prime example, no proper debate. I find now, and have done for some time, that I can only tolerate about half the programme before retiring with a good work of fiction.On Thursday evening the five members of the audience who were invited to participate, before I switched off and went to bed, were all vehemently opposed to the SNP, including as Mr Smith pointed, out one who was a Ukip member of the Orange Lodge, entitled to his opinion, however unchallenged in the "debate".In his last few years I felt David Dimbleby had lost control and Fiona Bruce, his replacement, whom I admire as a newsreader and presenter, lacks the incisive qualities of, for example, Emily Maitlis, who has proved on Newsnight she has the ability.The same  participants also seem to appear every few weeks asthe BBC has a limited pool of participants. Time for the BBC to review where this once-great programme is heading, or has the Brexit issue finally brought it to the point of no recovery Wallace Milligan, Juniper Green, Masonhill, Ayr.MARK Smithrsquos assessment of the BBCrsquos Question Time in Motherwell was charitable indeed. He gives the BBC the benefit of the doubt after allowing a known Ukip activist his fourth opportunity to shout at the SNP on the programme. This love-in between the BBC and Ukip has been longstanding, given the number of appearances Nigel Farage has had on the programme in recent years.The continued and sustained lack of SNP politicians appearing despite being the third largest party at Westminster compares badly with the treatment of the Liberal Democrats when they were in an identical parliamentary position. The truth is that the BBC has failed in its service to Scotland. The pound million Scotlandrsquos licence fee payers send south should instead be used to fund a new BBC Scotland, with complete editorial independence from the BBC in London. Before anyone complains that this would provide a poor service given a budget of this size, please be aware that Irelandrsquos BBC, which is known as RTE, spent eurom Ein .The New BBC Scotland would have at least the same spending power as RTE.Francis Buchan, Drybrough Crescent, Edinburgh.LAST Thursday on BBC Question Time from Motherwell, a serial audience member, former Ukip candidate Billy Mitchell, popped up in his favourite orange jerkin for his fourth appearance in so many years. This is a breach of the QT rules. A stooshie ensued on social media. Was he a far right plant by a Unionist-leaning editorial team, or had he sneaked in because of a flawed vetting procedure  I made it clear I thought cock-up, not conspiracy was the answer.That didnrsquot stop Mark Smith weighing in yesterday, writing a piece in which he described my position ndash that is, rejecting a conspiracy ndash as ldquocrappy, conspiratorial Da Vinci Code thinking. I know, surreal.Mr Smith also had an eccentric take on Mr Mitchellrsquos choice of orange jacket it was no more signicant than SNP list Fiona Hysloprsquos blue jacket. However a wee bit of googling would have alerted him to the fact that Mr Mitchell is a supporter of Ulster Young Militants, and calls himself "orange jacket man" on Facebook. So I donrsquot think itrsquos unreasonable to assume that his choice of jacket was a self-conscious sartorial nod.Why does it all matter  Well because Question Time producers say they have clear rules be up front about who you are when you apply to be on the programme, no repeat audience appearances, and politicians arenrsquot allowed to take cover in the audience ndash their place is on the  where they can be identied and their views subjected to scrutiny. Thatrsquos something surely we can all agree on John Nicolson,Presenter, TalkRadio, Hatfields, LondonAS they always do when theyre found out, Nationalists are claiming the Question Time audience was rigged and looking for dirt on Billy Mitchell. No wonder. The "Scotland is fed up to the back teeth of the SNP" genie was brutally hurled out of the bottle in front of millions of UK TV and social media viewers, never to .Mitchells final flourish: "Ye need tae get voted oot and leave Scotland tae prosper," was a clear challenge to opposition parties to up their game and finish the job in .Allan Sutherland, Willow Row, Stonehaven.Read more: Mark Smith on the Question Time row

title: glasgows-city-urbanist-nearly-40k-a-year-for-two-days-a-week
story: As told in the Evening Times last month, Glasgow City Council has employed Scotlands first City Urbanist to oversee Glasgows future development.Council leader Susan Aitken has hailed the appointment of Professor Brian Evans as a forward-thinking addition to the councils strategic planning.But Professor Evans, an expert in urbanism and landscape at the Glasgow School of Art, will be earning pound a day.Working two days a week, that comes to around pound, a year for each year of his three-year tenure.Local councillor Martin McElroy said: "After  years of budget cuts from the Edinburgh Government and staff reductions within every department in the council, I was surprised that this appointment has been seen as a priority for the Administration."Irsquom not sure too many people actually know what a City Urbanist is so we will need to wait and seethis appointment is worth the money."But I wish Prof Evans the best of luck in his new role, I hope he engages positively with businesses and elected members during his tenure."Prof Evans appointment was made through a private recruitment firm that Glasgow City Council paid pound, to "carry out an international search for an appropriate candidate," according to the response to a freedom of information request.Glasgows council has said it wants the city to be the "best liveable city" in Scotland with Prof Evans engaged to oversee how planning, development and transport can link up to best benefit communities.He will not, however, be able to veto planning decisions.Councillor Greg Hepburn, chairman of the Neighbourhoods, Housing and Public Realm Committee, said: ldquoThe role of the City Urbanist will be integral to making our communities cleaner, healthier and more vibrant places to live, work and visit ndash and Irsquom confident that every neighbourhood across Glasgow will benefit over the coming years."The fact that Labour doesnrsquot value that as something worth investing in only goes to show their lack of ambition for our city."Itrsquos a pity that Cllr McElroy didnrsquot discover his frugal streak a little earlier, when he and his colleagues were racking up millions in legal bills trying to avoid giving women equal pay."

title: yougov-poll-finds-snp-would-gain-four-seats-in-snap-general-election
story: According to the new poll, while the Scottish National Partys share of the vote was unchanged since  on %, but the YouGov model suggested they could boost their tally of Westminster seats by four to .:Brexit: Senior SNP source says Peoples Vote is deadThere was an overall drop for both the Conservatives and Labour.The YouGov survey for The Times found that Conservatives would increase their -seat tally by four to , with Labour shedding  MPs to end up with .While such a result would leave Mrs May short of commanding half of Parliaments  MPs, she could expect a wafer-thin working majority due to the fact that the Speaker and his deputies do not vote and Sinn Feins MPs do not traditionally take their seats.:Herald poll: Scotland should have independence referendum after BrexitIf Sinn Fein held on to its seven seats, Mrs May could expect a working majority of just one or two in the Commons and would be highly vulnerable to rebellions by backbenchers in her own party.In practice, she might well find herself once more dependent on the votes of the Democratic Unionist Party.The poll of more than , voters in England, Scotland and Wales used a model of assessing inidual constituencies which correctly predicted a hung Parliament in , when most pollsters were forecasting a comfortable Tory victory.It put Conservatives on % - down four points from the % recorded in British seats in  - but predicted a larger drop in support for Jeremy Corbyns Labour, down seven points from % in  to % now.Liberal Democrats were on %, up three points from the last election. And Ukip, which slumped to % in , experienced a resurgence to hit %, taking a signicant chunk of support from the Tories.YouGov questioned , British adults form February  to  and applied the results to the demographics of each inidual constituency to work out local swings.

title: diageos-whisky-tourism-centre-plan-for-former-house-of-fraser-in-princes-street-unveiled
story: The attraction is intended to be the focal point of a pound million investment in Scotch whisky tourism by Diageo, the drinksgiant said.The planning application, jointly submitted by Diageo and the building owner Parabola, sets out proposals for aseven-floor visitor experience at  Princes Street.The proposals would see the "meticulous restoration of the building with its many beautul heritage features preserved where possible and integrated into the new development".This will include restoring the famous clock on the corner of Princes Street and Hope Street ndashknown locally as the Binns corner after the former department store - which was earlier an Edinburgh institution and traditional meeting point for city residents.Most recently it was home to House of Fraser.Read more: Diageo very confident over Princes Street Johnnie Walker whisky centre bidIt says it will include a"multi-sensory, immersive visitor experience" across three floors, guiding people through the  year history of the brand, the art and science of whisky-making, and taking them on a journey through the flavours of Scotland.Diageo said the centre will be aflexible events space for staging music, theatre, arts and community events, making the venue part of the thriving cultural le of the city.It will also house abar academy that will be a home for Diageorsquos Learning for Le programme, which creates training and employment opportunities in the hospitality industry for unemployed people, and works to improve hospitality standards and promotes the responsible serving and consumption of alcohol.There will also be roof-top bars with views of Edinburgh Castle and across the city skyline to east, west and north, "with the intention of making it one of the worldrsquos most extraordinary iconic hospitality destinations".Read moreDiageo plays down Brexit impact as shares hit all-time highEconomic projections for the plan indicate it will create between  and  full time equivalent jobs and generate poundm in tourism spend.It is claimed the development also creates a powerful strategic opportunity for Edinburgh city centre, establishing a major attraction in the west end, helping to balance visitor footfall across the city.David Cutter, hairman of Diageo in Scotland, said: "We are incredibly excited to be able to submit our plans for the Johnnie Walker visitor experience in Edinburgh."The location is one of Edinburghrsquos most exceptional landmark buildings and we plan to restore it to its former glory as a cornerstone of the city and a thriving part of its cultural and social le."We have the most passionate and skilled whisky-makers in the world here in Scotland and we want to celebrate their craft and everything that is great about Scotland and whisky.Read more:Scotch giant fears for small firms as Brexit saga drags onTony Hordon, managing director of Parabola, said: "With Diageo and their vision, we believe we have a use which will not only protect the building for many years to come, but it also celebrates the building, its history, and its heritage."Diageo is currently investing over poundmin Scotch whisky experiences in Scotland.As well as the Edinburgh location, the company is also investing to transform its existing  distillery visitor attractions across Scotland and a poundminvestment to reopen the iconic distilleries of Port Ellen and Brora.

title: mps-must-hold-their-nerve-over-brexit-says-theresa-may
story: Theresa May is due to update the Commons later on the latest developments in negotiations with Brussels and Dublin, as the sides try to find a way through the impasse on measures for the Irish border.Downing Street said Mrs Mays statement, which comes a day earlier than expected, will give MPs more time to "digest the content" ahead of a series of expected Commons votes on Thursday.:Nicola Sturgeon: Scotland will be independent in five yearsMrs May is expected to say: "The talks are at a crucial stage. We now all need to hold our nerve to get the changes this House has required and deliver Brexit on time."By getting the changes we need to the backstop by protecting and enhancing workers rights and environmental protections and by enhancing the role of Parliament in the next phase of negotiations I believe we can reach a deal that this House can support."Talks are continuing apace between the UK and EU, with Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay and Mrs Mays de facto deputy, David Lidington, meeting MEPs in Strasbourg on Tuesday.Mr Barclay was said to have held "constructive" talks on Monday night with the EUs chief negotiator Michel Barnier in Brussels.The pair agreed to further meetings in the coming days, while their teams will continue to work to find a way forward.:David Watt: If the boss of Jaguar Land Rover says job losses are likely, then believe him, not a spokesperson for the European Research GroupMeanwhile, Sky News reported the former president of the European Council, Herman Van Rompuy, had dinner with Mr Lidington in Brussels on Monday night.Mr Van Rompuy has been tipped as a potential "influencer" to break the Brexit deadlock, the broadcaster reported.Negotiations of a kind have also been taking place back in Westminster, with an exchange of letters between Mrs May and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.However, a Cabinet minister insisted there is "no chance" of Mrs May accepting Labours vision for leaving the EU, despite speculation she could soften her stance on customs union membership.In an exclusive interview with the Press Association, Commons leader Andrea Leadsom dismissed the prospect of Mrs May adopting Mr Corbyns "world view".Mrs Leadsom, an ardent Leaver, said she would stay in the Cabinet to help Mrs May deliver Brexit and denied that the PM was softening her stance over a customs union in a letter to Mr Corbyn.Mrs Mays reply sparked concern among Conservative Brexiteers that the Prime Minister could concede too much ground to Labour in an attempt to win cross-party backing for a deal with Brussels.Mrs Leadsom said: "I think shes making quite clear that what Corbyn is demanding is actually not as good as what the Prime Ministers deal is offering."So he wants a customs union and he is unclear as to whether that means he also wants an independent trade policy."Hes unclear as to whether he also wants to stop free movement, and of course the EUs view would be, well,youre in the customs union then you have free movement and you abide by the common external tarf."I think theres no doubt that what the Prime Minister is offering is better than what Corbyn is demanding, which simply begs the question,they like it, why dont they vote for it "Mrs Leadsom said there was "no chance" Mrs May would adopt Mr Corbyns "view of the world", adding: "The Prime Minister has been absolutely clear were leaving the EU, were leaving the customs union, were leaving the single market."The frontbencher refused to say what the cut-off date would be for the necessary legislation to get through the Commons to allow the UK to leave the EU as planned on March .She said it was possible to pass bills "quite quickly" with "goodwill" from the Commons and Lords, but added: "Its just not possible to say how quickly it could be done."

title: george-clooney-meghan-markle-vilified-like-princess-diana
story: The actor, who is a friend of Harry and Meghans, said "history is repeating itself" and "weve seen how that ends".His intervention comes amid reports of a rt between the Duchess of Sussex and her father Thomas Markle.A newspaper published a letter apparently written by Mr Markle months after he missed her wedding.Read more:The disgraceful white-washing of Meghan MarkleThe Hollywood star is a friend of Harry and Meghan and he and his human rights lawyer we Amal attended the royal wedding in May last year.After joking about a report suggesting he would be named godfather to Harry and Meghans baby, Clooney, , who was speaking at an event in Los Angeles, said: "I do want to say, I just saw this piece."Theyre just chasing Meghan Markle everywhere, shes been pursued and vilied."Shes a woman who is seven months pregnant and she is being pursued and vilied and chased in the same way that Diana was, and its history repeating itself."And weve seen how that ends."I cant tell you how frustrating it is to see that."Youre taking a letter from a daughter to a father and broadcasting it everywhere."Shes getting a raw deal there, its irresponsible."Im sort of surprised by that."Read more:Meghan Markle and Kate Middletons royal catfight reports were inevitableClooney and his we have -month-old twins, daughter, Ella, and a son, Alexander.Askedhe was going to be godfather to the royal baby, he said: "No, Im now a father of twins, Ive got enough shit. Literally, literally shit."Former actress Meghan, , is estranged from her father after a string of high-profile incidents since she became engaged to Harry.Days before his daughter was due to marry into the royal family, Mr Markle allegedly staged paparazzi photos of himself.He has previously said his relationship with his daughter has broken down and has made public appeals for her to get in touch with him, including an appearance on Good Morning Britain.Read more:In pictures: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle on first joint visit to ScotlandMr Markle, speaking to the Mail On Sunday this week, dismissed claims he has not attempted to contact his daughter.An unnamed friend of Los Angeles-born Meghan told US magazine People: "Hes never called hes never texted. Its super painful."Five nameless friends of the duchess spoke to People in an effort to counter the "global bullying" directed at her.Meghan revealed in January that her baby is due around the end of April or beginning of May.

title: theresa-may-accused-of-running-down-the-clock-on-brexit
story: Addressing the House of Commons a fortnight after MPs voted for her to go back to Brussels and replace the controversial Irish border backstop, Mrs May acknowledged that she would need "some time" to hold talks with the EU.:MPs must hold their nerve over Brexit says Theresa MayShe said that a planned Commons debate on Thursday will be on an amendable motion reaffirming the Houses decision on January  that it supported the Governments efforts to find an alternative for the backstop and recognising that talks are ongoing.Mrs May pledged toto Parliament on February ,no deal has been secured before that time, to report back on progress and trigger a further MPs vote the following day."We now all need to hold our nerve to get the changes this House requires and deliver Brexit on time," Mrs May told the Commons."By getting the changes we need to the backstop by protecting and enhancing workers rights and environmental protections and by enhancing the role of Parliament in the next phase of negotiations I believe we can reach a deal that this House can support."We can deliver for the people and the communities that voted for change two-and-a-half years ago - and whose voices for too long have not been heard."We can honour the result of the referendum."And we can set this country on course for the bright future that every part of this United Kingdom deserves."That is this Governments mission. We shall not stint in our efforts to fulfil it."Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn accused the PM of "running down the clock" in the hope that MPs will be "blackmailed" by the fear of a no-deal Brexit into supporting "a deeply flawed deal".:Theresa May backs Chris Grayling after cancellation of ferry contract awarded to a firm with no ships"This is an irresponsible act," said Mr Corbyn. "She is playing for time and playing with peoples jobs, our economic security and the future of our industry."Mr Corbyn accused Mrs May of refusing to listen to his alternative deal, involving permanent customs union membership, a close alignment with the single market and matching EU workplace and environmental protections."I urge all members across this House to think about the damage the Prime Ministers strategy is doing - the threat to industry and skilled jobs in communities across Britain," he said."Now is not the time to stand idly by, now is the time to stand up and do the right thing: to rule out no deal and back Labours alternative plan."

title: background-music-is-a-human-rights-violation-say-campaigners
story: But background music has become the centre of a new campaign to support the elderly, hard of hearing or autistic people, as well as those who just find it annoying.The group Quiet Scotland argues that ldquopiped music, played by shops, cafes and restaurants can be ldquodistressing to people who would prefer a quieter environment.The campaign started in , and has around  members from around Scotland.It began as an offshoot of the Pipedown campaign, based in England, and initially campaigned against background music in Edinburgh.It has since expanded to cover the whole of Scotland, and publishes a list of ldquomuzac-free locations in Edinburgh and Glasgow, for other haters of background music to visit.The group also encourages retailers that eschew piped music to contact the group and be placed on the list. It says that playing loud music in public places amounts to a violation of human rights.Quiet Scotland has designed a set of feedback cards that allow customers to rate cafes, restaurants and bars on the loudness of their music.The cards are available from the group on request, and it hopes that they will persuade cafe owners and retailers to turn the music off. It also suggests that the grouprsquos followers contact the managers or owners of businesses to complain about the loudness of music.The pub chain Wetherspoons has already banned background music in its branches, and some supermarkets have introduced ldquoquiet hours where their music is switched off.Discount retailers Aldi and Lidl do not play any music in their branches.The Herald tested six venues in Glasgow with a decibel meter and found that one store ndash JD Sports ndash had music in its branch as loud as  decibels, which is as loud as a lawnmower. Its average was  decibels.By law, workers exposed to average noise levels of more than  decibels must be provided with ear protection.The Nike sports shop, which plays music in its branches, measured  on the decibel meter. Branches of Starbucks and Pizza Hut in the town centre, meanwhile, measured  and  decibels respectively.The Counting House Wetherspoons on George Square in Glasgow ndashwhich doesnrsquot play music ndash measured  decibels, the quietest venue tested.Quiet Scotlandrsquos treasurer, Anne Wellman, , said while the group began as an offshoot of Pipedown in England, they changed its name because ldquopiped music has a dferent meaning in Scotland.ldquoWe changed it to Quiet Scotland, because everybody who joined intensely dislikes background music played in public places, she said.ldquoSometimes thatrsquos because of health conditions, but in many cases itrsquos merely because we dislike having music imposed upon us.ldquoIn most cases, the music that shops and cafes play is unlikely to be popular with customers, she said. ldquoThink of the types of music you donrsquot like, and then have that blasted at you when yoursquore trying to eat. Because thatrsquos mostly the case.ldquoWhat are the odds of them playing something you actually like ldquoIt is very distressing for people who have a medical condition like autism or tinnitus or any hearing problems.She also suggested that disability legislation designed to protect those with medical conditions from discrimination could be applied to the loudness of music in public places.ldquoIt can actually affect your health and put you off going into shops and restaurants, she said.ldquoFor a lot of people, itrsquos simply annoying, but annoying to the point of refusing to patronise thoseshops.ldquoWe have about  members and we have a Facebook and Twitter presence which is gaining followers.ldquoI would make a comparison with the anti-smoking campaign. There was a point at which that was laughed at, and then it reached a tipping point when people actually started to agree.ldquoWe do see it as a transgression of a human right.The group also claims that rather than attracting more customers, loud background music can drive sales away, with customers preferring to shop online or in quieter places.Even pubs that choose not to playmusic can have televisions or gambling machines that make conversation dficult, it says.Background music has drawn the attention of celebrities, including Joanna Lumley, Stephen Fry and Roger Scruton, the conservative intellectual.

title: st-mirren-vow-to-find-and-ban-fans-who-spat-at-unconscious-supporter
story: Buddies chiefs have hit out at the "completely and utterly unacceptable" behaviour of a small group of fans on Saturday.The United supporter was injured while celebrating one of the Ladbrokes Championship outfits goals during their - win in Paisley.But in a statement posted on the Saints website, club officials claim he was targeted by a section of the home support as he was being led away for treatment.Read more:Police Scotland accused of trying to turn young football fans into paid informants"On Saturday a Dundee Utd supporter suffered a serious head injury after the away crowd surged forward after Uniteds first goal," the statement said. "This is something we have warned our own support against on numerous occasions so hopefully this will make people realise how dangerous this can be."Given the seriousness of the injury the decision was taken to remove the fan by the quickest means possible which was through the vomitory at W."While the unconscious supporter was being removed there were numerous people standing above the vomitory who decided to spit and throw coins at him."This is completely and utterly unacceptable. We cannot allow the actions of a very small number of fans to ruin the reputation of St Mirren Football Club."Some of the people responsible were identied but unfortunately the quality of the CCTV footage of the incident is such that at this time we are unable to pursue this to the degree of certainty that would allow prosecution."If we are able to clearly identy the culprits, regardless of what happens in a legal sense, they will be given a letime ban from our stadium.Read more:Police warning to football fans over crackdown on coin-throwing"We would ask anyone with any information or footage of the incident to contact the club on info@stmirren."Any information provided will be treated in the strictest confidence."For the avoidance of any doubt antisocial behaviour will not be tolerated in ANY area of our stadium."A spokeswoman for Police Scotland said: "We were contacted by the club about an incident and enquiries are ongoing."

story: A Kemnay man ascended Bennachie  times in just one year.Craig Thomson completed the achievement on Sunday, December , .His friend, Ross Henderson, joined Craig on the milestone expedition.Ross said: “I met Craig back in  and a few months after, he spoke about wanting to do Bennachie  times in a year.“The main motivation behind this was the memory of a friend of his, Malcolm, who died of Neuofibromatosis.“Malcolm succombed to the condition shortly after he and Craig had completed an ascent of Bennachie so it is entirely fitting that he should complete such a challenge.”“I quite often saw Craig’s car heading out towards Bennachie on many an occasion, sometimes when it was dark.“I did join him on a few expeditions out on the hill, one of them we timed well as we ed to the car park when it was dusky.“I hadn’t heard much from Craig until a few days before Christmas when he sent me a text askingI wanted to join him for the th ascent.“On the day a few of us met up at the back of Bennachie car park, there were  of us and three dogs so an excellent turnout.“He handed us all a program for the day which contained a written discription of his previous ascents and how he had built up to the full .“In  he managed  and in  he reached  and then stopped counting as it was getting late in the year.”The group set off and after an hour or so they had reached the summit of Oxen Craig, Bennachie’s highest peak.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as virtual reality and articial intelligence, it is important that young people see and hear first-hand what the future of the industry looks like and the vast and exciting opportunities these developments present to them.”Attracting young talent remains a key focus for the sector.The recent OPITO UKCS Workforce Dynamics Review showed thatthe sector achieves its ambitions set out in Vision ,, people will need to be recruited over the next two decades.Around , of those are expected to be in roles that don’t yet exist.Mr McDonald added: “We are currently developing a new UKCS Skills Strategy to support the skills that will be required by both new and existing personnel operating in the North Sea into the next decade.“It is important we provide opportunities through initiatives like EYF to help young people discover that this is a sector with a future worth considering that also has the learning infrastructure in place to help develop their career and unlock their potential.”The pupils taking part were all aged between  to . The other schools at the event were Aberdeen Grammar, the International School Aberdeen, Oldmachar Academy, Albyn School, Mintlaw Academy, Robert Gordon’s College and Peterhead Academy.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Jemima Adeoye, Director of Education and Childrens Services Laurence Findlay, Elizabeth Lyall, Cooper Masson, Cllr Gillian Owen, Cllr Jim Gford, Provost Bill Howatson, Chief Executive Jim Savege, Tami Fadeyi, Ruaridh Cumming and Head Teacher Pamela Farquhar with pupils outside the new Kinellar School"  Community celebrates official opening of Kinellar School viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: how the uk visas and immigration department is preparing for brexit
story: It expires after . years and costs about £, each time. Howrsquos the immigration department preparing for Brexit  I foresee massive wait times. What will that mean for my husband and his status - including his right to work  How the UK Visas and Immigration department is preparing for BrexitA. After March , EU citizens will need to apply for settled or pre-settled status to remain in the UK. This obviously wont apply to your husband as he is Japanese but I can see why you are concerned about increased waiting timesmost EU citizens do need to contact the UK Visas and Immigration department at a similar time.The good news is that the deadline for applying will be June , ,we leave with a deal in place, or December ,  without a deal, so hopefully applications will be spread out over that time period.Read more: How Brexit will affect every ingredient of a full English breakfastTo prepare, the UK Visas and Immigration department, under the Home Office, is opening new service centres in Manchester, Birmingham, Glasgow, Cardf, Belfast and Croydon to help people applying for work or study visas, settlement or citizenship from within the UK. There will also be  enhanced service centres nationally for people who are willing to pay for things like same day appointments, and on-demand services, along with a premium loungein London. An additional seven dedicated Service and Support Centres will be located in in Belfast, Cardf, Croydon, Glasgow, Liverpool, Sheffield and Solihull for anyone who needs more support with their applications.All of this should help ease the burden and decrease delays. However, even the best laid plans can go wrong, especially when it involves such a large initiative, so what would happenyour husband didnt get his visa back in time Well, the government has confirmed that, providing he makes his application at least  days before his visa ends, that his immigration status will stay the same..Hersquoll still have the right to work, access education and receive benefits while he waits for a new visa..Do you have a Brexit-related question  Email gemma.jimmison@jpressdata-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.kirkintilloch-herald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Photograph Jamie Forbes ..St Marys Church, Kirkintilloch. title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. Inspectors said this will enable practitioners to identy what is working well and what needs to improve.They also want to see development of approaches to assessment and planning to help improve the quality of learning experiences and provide “greater depth and challenge” for all children.Improvements are also being sought in the development of practitioners’ knowledge and understanding of how to support children’s early language and mathematical thinking.Inspectors are confident that the setting has the capacity to continue to improve and will make no more visits in connection with this inspection.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The group at the summit of Oxen Craig - Craig Thomson is pictured th left"  Craig ascends Bennachie  times viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: photo competition extended
story: The deadline for our exclusive photo competition has been extended giving you, our readers, more time to get your shots to us.We have teamed up with CALA Homes to award one lucky reader with a Canon SLR camera worth £.Keen photographers in the Inverurie area are invited to take part in the competition by submitting images which demonstrate what the town means to them.We would like to see photos which capture the essence of Inverurie: the friendly community and lively town centre, beautul views, striking landscapes or its wonderful wildle.To get involved, simply submit a single photo along with your name, address and telephone number to the iheartinverurie@beattiegroup email address.You can also upload your entry via the CALA Homes Facebook and Twitter pages tagging CALA Homes and the Inverurie Herald and using #iheartinverurie.The CALA judging  will pick five finalists and readers will get the chance to vote for the winner.The winning photograph will be displayed in the sales suite at The Grove development in Inverurie.The competition will now close on Thursday, February  so get your images to us and you could be the proud owner of a fantastic new Canon SLR camera!data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Meldrum Academy pupils James Padmos and Max Walker with David Wavell from The ORCA Hub"  Virtual subsea work for Meldrum pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: strong entry of calves for spring show
story: Some of the best commercial calves in the country will be forward at the Royal Northern Spring Show, held in conjunction with Aberdeen and Northern Marts.The annual event, which will be held at the Thainstone Centre on Wednesday, February , has attracted a strong entry of  calves from noted breeders.John and Craig Robertson from Newton of Logierait, Pitlochry, regularly dominate the show and sale, having scooped the supreme championship six times since . Last year, they sold the top price animal at £, for their champion heer and sold three others for £,, £, and £,.This year, the Robertsons have  calves entered including a full sister to last year’s top price heer.Huntly and Insch duo, Blair Duffton and Rebecca Stuart, will alsoto this year’s event with five calves, as will Ian Miller of Miller Farms, North Lurg, Midmar, who has four calves entered.Judging the commercial cattle entries, which will occur following the show and sales of bulls, will be well-known pedigree and commercial producer, Melanie Alford.John Angus, head of livestock at Thainstone, said: “The livestock sale element of the Royal Northern Spring Show is a fast-growing part of the event and we are delighted to be working once again with the Royal Northern Agricultural Society. The Spring Show is now recognised as the number one place for buyers from near and far to come and source quality calves with further showing potential.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"DIGG Councillor Martin Ford"  Councillors keen to prevent cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. title: german company revealed as third bidder for northern isles ferry tender
story: INTERNATIONAL ferry company FRS Group have been revealed as the third bidder for the Northern Isles ferry service.The company, headquartered in Flensburg, Germany, confirmed the news this week.#FRS follows the tender process. But please understand that we will not disclose any further information on this tender at this time.#It was last month that the Scottish Government stated that an invitation to tender for the next contract to run the Northern Isles ferry services had been issued to three bidders.The names of the companies involved were not released by the government, however Serco NorthLink and Calmac did confirm their involvement.When asked last month, previous bidder Streamline confirmed that it was not one of the bidders on this occasion, leading to speculation over the final company involved.Submission of final tenders is scheduled for March, with a view to awarding the contract in July, said the Scottish Government. The contract is estimated to be worth £m, and will run for eight years.FRS Group runs ferry services throughout many areas of the world, including Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and North America.The organisation is also involved in maritime consultancy and offshore logistics.According to the company, FRS has grown from a regional passenger ferry operator into an internationally active group with  vessels and more than , employees from more than a dozen countries all over the world.FRS annually carries . million passengers and . million vehicles on its numerous national and international shipping lines.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
